If you want to spread untruths, I will condemn you continually for it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd, Jim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to express my concern and anger at the New South Wales Labor government's vicious tax slug on registered clubs. In my electorate on the Central Coast of New South Wales, registered clubs play a vital part in our community. This vicious attack by the Carr Labor government on registered clubs will have a devastating effect on our community.

SPEECH.PARA: I have before me extracts from some of the local newspapers. The Central Coast Express Advocate has the heading, `Clubs in crisis'. An editorial from Bob Staines, the editor of the Central Coast Express Advocate, is headed, `Dump rise or be kicked out'. That is the effect that those tax rises are having on our community. The people of the Central Coast are outraged. Communities on the Central Coast rely on their local clubs, which input a huge amount of money to the communities of the Central Coast.

As the federal member for Robertson, I have been working very hard to stimulate growth and employment on the Central Coast of New South Wales. I have been particularly involved in the community of Ettalong, through their main street program and through the work of people like Deborah Wales. I was thrilled when we launched the New South Wales black spot funding in the community of Ettalong. The reason that community was selected to launch the New South Wales black spot funding was the fact that the community had raised a large amount of money from the shop owners and the registered club—the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club—to input into the construction of a roundabout to save lives and to help employment in Ettalong. All this sort of funding is now put at risk, simply because of this tax slug from the New South Wales Labor government. They have no consideration for the effect it is having.

BREAK.PARA: It appears that the New South Wales government is trying to undermine all the good work that the federal government is putting into the Central Coast of New South Wales. Already we have had difficulties with the establishment of our international garden festival—the Planet Earth 2000 project—where the New South Wales government seemed to be intent on causing difficulties for the establishment of that project. I am pleased that that project is still going ahead. As I mentioned, there is now a real possibility that the black spot funding may be undermined because of the lack of community contributions that would have come from the clubs.
I have quotes here from the manager of the Ettalong Beach War Memorial Club. They had major plans for upgrading. The manager, Peter Hale, quoted in the Central Coast Express Advocate this week, said:
. . . a $45 million project to rebuild the Ettalong club, including a 200‐room hotel, was now under review.

This project was the lifeblood of the township of Ettalong, a township made up of hardworking, battling Australians. This project was the economic stimulus to get this town moving again. All this has been put under threat by this ridiculous increase in turnover tax.

According to Mr Hale, this tax will cost 500 jobs over two years. Mr Hale also said that typical sponsorship was threatened to clubs such as the Umina Beach Surf Club, which the club was sponsoring for $75,000 over three years. This is just one of the examples of the good work that is done by the Central Coast registered clubs. The Central Coast Leagues Club, one of the biggest clubs in New South Wales, also stated that many of its community projects are at risk. The Central Coast Leagues Club gives assistance totalling $5 million a year to the community, and to cricket, rugby league, soccer, Aussie rules and other sporting groups. All these sorts of projects are now at risk, simply because of the tax grab from the New South Wales Labor government.

Again this year the federal government has brought down a budget which has created an environment that will give opportunities for all our children and for a responsible, finan cially sound future, which we have been looking forward to. But, on the Central Coast of New South Wales, all these opportunities are being undermined by the New South Wales Labor government and by its turnover tax for registered clubs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the years, I have attended hundreds of naturalisation ceremonies and been associated with parliamentary colleagues from the state and federal parliaments and from the Liberal Party who, on every occasion, have extended their congratulations and best wishes to those people of Asian origin who chose to become Australian citizens. I have never had any reason to doubt their sincerity and I now know that members on both sides of this House deplore the incoherent and racist attitude that has been displayed, not merely in this parliament but outside this parliament, by the honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). She has the support of longstanding racist organisations who are only too happy to provide her with a platform—I refer to the racist and anti‐Semitic organisation known as the League of Rights. In over 30 years in politics, I have never heard any member of any parliament say of one group of constituents, `I will not deal with you, I will not represent you, for no other reason than that you belong to an indigenous group of citizens,' and I, of course, refer to the Aboriginal citizens of Oxley.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the important aspects of this place is the unique position enjoyed by the Prime Minister, who has not only a role of political leadership over and beyond his direct political responsibilities to his party but also a moral authority. For some months now editorial writers, religious leaders and leaders of the ethnic communities have been asking the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to give a lead on this important issue and to demonstrate that in no way does the member for Oxley represent the broad views, or even the narrow views, of members of this House and the Australian community generally.

For months now church leaders, multicultural leaders, editorial writers and community leaders have been looking for that state ment—not just on the basis that our trade with Asia would be affected or that the tourism industry in Queensland would be affected but on the basis that, over the years, ministers for immigration on both sides of politics have done a great deal to develop the sort of society in which we live: a multicultural society.

The Prime Minister well knows—I do not have to remind him—that in my electorate there are many citizens who were victims of Hitler's holocaust. They learnt, through painful experience, that the first exercise before you got to the concentration camps or the gas chambers was to dehumanise the Jewish people so that they were not real people—they were a vague threat in all sorts of ways. There is no place in Australian society for that position to be developed against any member of our community.

Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) indicated that, due to the attitudes of the member for Oxley, there is no way she would get the preferences of the Labor Party, that she would be at the bottom of the ticket, and he invited the Prime Minister to adopt such a lead. I would have understood if the Prime Minister had said, `I would like to talk to my party about it.' I would have understood if he had said, `I would like to think about it.' But what we got was a pathetic no.

I believe that, in adopting that position, the Prime Minister not merely failed to give an effective lead to his own party but also failed to give an effective lead to the people of Australia. I believe that very short answer, coming as a fairly pathetic response, will come back to haunt him. I urge him to rethink his position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this year a mobile phone tower was constructed in Murrumba Downs, a suburb in the northern reaches of my electorate. I know that the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), who is at the table, is interested in this issue as well. It is pleasing to see him here. Having read his very early speech on this subject, I think he is certainly someone who has assisted me in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular tower is an absolute blot on the landscape. It was erected in the space of one morning. It does not give me much pleasure to say this, but it is the product of an unholy alliance, in my view, between Vodafone and a local church which has seen fit to overlook the concerns of local residents in favour of the return to be derived from leasing part of its land to the mobile phone provider.

I say `an unholy alliance' because Queensland churches anyway—I do not know about other parts of Australia—are put at a very significant advantage in the community in that they have a rates exemption because they carry on an activity of religious instruction and education, and otherwise ceremony and tradition. So they get a rates allowance.

For a church to abuse, in my view, that special privilege by entering into a commercial deal with a phone carrier is totally unacceptable and something that the state government, maybe even the federal government, has to look at. Certainly, the state government could use the Local Government Act, but perhaps the federal government should bring some influence to bear there.

The positioning of the tower is alarming. It is in very close proximity to the Undurba State School and Inverpine Retirement Village and is immediately adjacent to a kindergarten. It is also flush‐up against the boundary of a neighbouring property. The particular person concerned was never consulted about the positioning of this tower by the church.

Concerned residents will be meeting at my office this coming week to discuss health and safety issues with independent expert, Dr Thiel of Griffith University. Vodafone representatives attending a recent meeting of the school P&C Association were asked by a parent whether Vodafone had ever moved a tower. One of the representatives replied, `No, and it is unlikely that we would ever do so.' To make matters worse, the facility erected by Vodafone, subject to local authority consent, could be upgraded or used by other service providers. As well as that, Murrumba Downs has another contaminant, namely, pay TV aerial cables. This time it is not Vodafone but Telstra. The residents of one street—which, incidentally, was promoted as a quality estate, with all underground services—have been told that they either get aerial cables, whether they want them or not, or, incredibly, they pay $300 to have them installed underground. They have until 27 May to decide.

I say `incredibly' because there is no demand, it appears, in the particular estate to have these so-called services. Telstra is saying, `If you want them underground you pay for them,' but they do not want them in the first place—an extraordinary non sequitur, I would have thought. The residents presented a petition to the local authority, the Pine Rivers Shire Council, about the Telstra plans but, until the new telecommunications code takes effect on 1 July 1997, it is powerless to intervene.

On the other side of my electorate, at Everton Park, another elderly constituent has found the Optus pay TV aerial cables and an attendant large black box affixed to the electricity poll near his home so intolerable that he feels like climbing the pole with bolt cutters to rid himself of the eyesore. In my electorate, Vodafone, Telstra and Optus have caused their share of distress. People are forced to cop this sort of thing and it is really unacceptable—1 July cannot come soon enough. These operators are making the most of the remaining month and a half to create as much havoc as they can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 8 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Prosser:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House will not detain the passage of this legislation for too long. I should signal at the outset that both the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1997, which are the bills under discussion this morning, are supported by the opposition. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) will be raising some issues associated with the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1997 that he believes need to be addressed. In the main, these are not, I think, controversial by their nature.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill, in fact, seeks to change the way in which excise duty is calculated and paid on stabilised crude petroleum oil from three times a month to once a month and will take effect from 1 July this year. These amendments are in conjunction with amendments which are contained in the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1997. The second thing that this bill does is to remove liquid petroleum gas, which is currently excise free, from the application of the tariff act. Thirdly, this specific bill decreases the excise duty on aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene by 0.75c per litre, with effect from 1 September 1997. This is as a result of an over‐collection of duty during 1995‐96.

The reductions also take account of the reduction in operating costs of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the forecast growth in airline activity. I am not sure about that reduction in operating costs for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority with the recent appointment there. I am sure, as time goes on, we will see how effective that is, with the pay‐off to the new deputy chairman of that organisation by the government.

This affords me the opportunity, whilst these two bills are within the House, to make a couple of passing comments in respect of petroleum and to actually pay a compliment to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser). It is not often, I suspect, when a budget is less than 24 hours old that an opportunity can be taken by the opposition to pay a compliment to a minister for having taken a decision which is fair and reasonable in all the circumstances and which probably has been long overdue.

I am talking, of course, about the crackdown on dangerous fuel substitution. I say to the minister that this is a very appropriate and timely decision the government has taken. As was announced last night in the budget, the government is going to clamp down on dangerous fuel substitution by introducing chemical tracers for concessional fuel. This should be bad news, as the minister pointed out in his press release, for shonky operators who sell fuel blends containing concessional and waste fuel products as automotive diesel in order to avoid tax. The concept embodied in that, of course, is very significant in terms of the bills that we are debating here this morning.

I point out, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your benefit and, I am sure, for the benefit of other members, that this is a practice which has been going on for some time. What has tended to emerge—certainly in metropolitan areas and in cities such as my own city of Wollongong—is the growth of service stations which are not linked directly to one of the major suppliers in this country. The effect of that is that people have been buying in fuel from different sources and, as a consequence, the mix that has been retailed by these smaller operators has probably not been the purest form of fuel that should be sold.

The effect that that has had is that it has been a real boon for automotive repair shops and automotive tuners in my electorate of Cunningham, because consumers who see that they are getting petrol which is often several cents cheaper than at a service station operated by Shell, Mobil, or whatever, on the opposite corner to them suddenly find that one or two uses of this fuel lead to dreadful engine problems in their vehicles. As a consequence, they have to take them off to automotive repairers, to people who are charged with the responsibility of tuning these engines up, and what they are finding is all manner of muck contained in that particular fuel blend.

I am delighted to see that the minister is here. Minister, I was just singing your praises for the budget initiative last night with respect to the crackdown on dangerous fuel substitution. Now that you are here, let me congratulate you, face to face. It is a measure that is long overdue. I was just relating some circumstances in my own electorate where, in recent times, this has been highlighted as a problem.

What we have done, on this side of the House, is conduct a price watch on petrol in a number of electorates. Over a few months now, one of the issues which is constantly coming up is the concern about the shonkier dealers, people who are buying fuel mixes which often contain sediment and have a whole range of other problems, or the mix that has been put into that fuel has been inappropriate. I was saying, Minister, that it has actually improved the opportunities for people who tune up vehicles to have a tremendous business in Wollongong, because a number of these service stations are now operating. So I say to you again that the measure that you announced last night in the budget is a very welcome one in that respect.

To return to the legislation before the Main Committee, the opposition has no problem with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997. We give it our unqualified support. I want to thank the minister for the opportunity that was provided to me and my staff for a briefing on this particular matter and the courteous way in which that briefing was conducted by officers of his department and from the Australian Customs Service. It is refreshing to see that level of cooperation and I appreciate it greatly. I wish this legislation speedy passage through the Main Committee and, indeed, through the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just say a few words on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1997. The Howard government came to office with simple promises to the Australian people: we promised to talk with Australians, not at them; we said we would give Australians a say in public policy and make public policy making a public matter once more. That is the principle that has made the Charter of Budget Honesty a keystone of fiscal responsibility at the federal level. It is a principle that has fuelled much‐needed reform to tax collections for the tax law improvement project; likewise with the small business deregulation task force.

BREAK.PARA: It gives me precious little satisfaction to learn that, as recently as March last year, this parliament was passing about three times as many acts as its Canadian or British counterparts and that the amount of paperwork generated by the parliament has expanded exponentially in recent years. These are not issues that are in some way irrelevant to the needs of the Australian community. The government's election policy said:

Complex and convoluted laws require lawyers to interpret them. The more complex the law, the longer the lawyer will take and the greater the cost. The average citizen has little hope of understanding the laws.

The prospect of lawyers profiting from the misfortune of the public and the inadequacy of the parliament does not please me, for one, nor the government as a whole. For this reason I am honoured to speak on the legislation before us.

The two bills we are addressing seek to clarify the law so as to ensure fair and efficient excise collection in the industries of stabilised crude petroleum oil, crude oil and liquid petroleum gas, better know as LPG. Instead of forcing producers to calculate excise amounts and make payments of excise 36 times a year, this concurrent legislation will increase the length of that prescribed division to a month. The result—one‐third the number of calculations of payments in a year—will help alleviate the administrative burden presently imposed on crude oil producers. The reforms will also reduce the government's meddling in this market.

These reforms are motivated by a commitment to greater flexibility and understanding on the part of government and reflect significant changes in the crude oil industry itself. In the mid‐1980s, the current excise system allowed the government to take advantage of the boom in Bass Strait crude oil production. In fact, it has been noted that in 1984‐85 $4.2 million was collected in this manner in excise payments. Since then, significant amendments have been made to the collection system as the crude oil market was deregulated and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987, which determines the volware price of crude oil, was passed. Yet the administrative mess that necessitated 36 annual payments and calculations remained.

Furthermore, the extension of the petroleum resource rent tax regime to Bass Strait reduced the number of payees to only three, excise collected on crude oil dived to $12.2 million in 1995‐96. It seems ridiculous to continue with such an outdated and burdensome system on such amounts of collectable excise.

Both the amendment bills before us have been developed by the government in full and open consultation with the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association. The amendments also ensure consistent treatment of LPG by making production of LPG excise exempt by removing LPG from the ambit of the tariff act. This will remove the administrative burden on producers of LPG and the government, and bring the treatment of offshore LPG production in line with onshore LPG production.
Amendments are also being made to the rates of excise duty on aviation gasoline, better known as avgas, and aviation kerosene, better known as avtur—a very welcome move in my own electorate.
In conclusion, I commend these two bills to the House and state to the parliament my hope that we will see similar legislation in many other areas of Commonwealth law and taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill 1997. They are appropriately being dealt with together as a package. In a strict portfolio sense, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), the shadow minister for small business and customs, has dealt directly with the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. As shadow minister for resources and energy, I propose, as my colleague the member for Cunningham indicated, to make some comments about the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister, in his second reading speeches on the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill in his own right and on the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill on behalf of the Minister for Resources (Senator Parer), detailed the arrangements to be effected by the package of legislation. In effect, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill change the way in which excise duty is calculated and paid on crude petroleum oil from three times a month to once a month from 1 July of this year. That bill removes liquid petroleum gas, which is currently excise free, from the application of the tariff act.

The Petroleum Excise (Prices) Amendment Bill reflects those changes and also removes the requirement to determine the volume weighted average of realised prices for oil producing regions which have exceeded the excise free threshold but have not produced oil at a rate which attracts an excise liability. It also removes the need to determine a reference price for oil for the following month.

These are technical provisions which provide for better administration. They are supported by industry. The relevant formal industry association, the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association—APPEA—supports these measures. They are supported by the opposition on the merits, but also because they were initiated by the now opposition when in government. They did not reach the stage of legislation, but the substantive decisions had been made prior to the last election. If they had reached the stage of legislation and been introduced by the member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), in his then capacity as Minister for Resources and Energy, I am sure his speeches would have been almost precisely the same as the speeches of the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) on the occasion that he introduced the bills in the House.

They are technical bills, but they reflect important policy and a shift in the nature of tax arrangements so far as the petroleum industry is concerned over the years. This was touched upon by the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) in his contribution. Basically, they reflect the change of taxation arrangements, so far as the petroleum industry is concerned, from excise or royalty to resources rent tax. That is a secondary tax, or a tax on profit, which is generally regarded by the petroleum industry—it is certainly regarded by those on this side of the parliament—as being a more appropriate taxation regime. It taxes profit. The petroleum industry, based as it is on the high risk of exploration, regards this as a more appropriate arrangement. Certainly, on our side of the House, we regard it as a much more effective arrangement.

Excise, so far as petroleum is concerned, is currently only payable on a small number of petroleum producing fields. Since the diminution of production in Bass Strait, we are really talking about the Jackson field in south‐west Queensland, the Harriet fields in Western Australia and, when production starts in the course of the next financial year, the Wannaea field in the North West Shelf region.

Whilst these bills and measures are technical, they do reflect some significant changes in the petroleum and oil industry over the years. In the 1970s and 1980s the crude oil regime represented the Commonwealth's most significant petroleum production taxation mechanism. In some years that collection was as high as $4 billion per annum. We are now in the hundred million range, or lower.

BREAK.PARA: As a result of a decline over those years in oil prices coupled with, as I have indicated, the development of the resources rent tax and movements in those areas, we have seen the Commonwealth's collection move more comprehensively to resources rent tax. We have also seen the diminution of Bass Strait as a production area. Whilst I am sure the member for Forrest and the Minister for Small Business, like me, puts on his selfish parochial cap and says that to some extent the expense of Bass Strait has been at the great burgeoning of the North West Shelf so far as the national mix is concerned, that has also been reflected by the Commonwealth's collections.

Those remaining crude oil areas which are excisable, as I have indicated, now come into the hundreds of millions or less, rather than the $4 billion peak. We are dealing with much smaller areas. The administrative and technical changes which are being made really reflect a significantly smaller volume production. Whilst the regime which is proposed to be amended by the bills was appropriate in earlier years for much larger production areas, it is administratively unsound for the current volume of production. It is administratively inefficient. The regime places an unnecessary burden, not on only the department but, also and more importantly, on industry. Consequently, these measures are supported without reservation by the opposition. Like my colleague the member for Cunningham, we compliment the minister on bringing it forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the speakers, the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) and the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith). I note the congratulations from the member for Cunningham on our initiatives in regard to fuel substitution. I am sure that as the Shadow Minister for Customs, he would also be pleased with our program to substantially upgrade the Customs marine fleet. I know that he has had some interest in the Customs area in the past and our initiative of $26 to $27 million over the four‐year period and the major upgrade of the Customs marine fleet both in size and number will help Customs in their role to secure our borders.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of these bills is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act 1987. As honourable members have stated, these bills are a legislative package which include, firstly, an alteration to the arrangements for the calculation and payment of excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil. The proposed amendment here reduces the calculation and payment of excise duty on stabilised crude oil from 36 times per financial year to 12 times per year—a significant cutting of red tape in anyone's language.

These amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 also require consequential amendments to the calculation of volware prices under the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act. It is proposed that these amendments will commence on 1 July 1997 to avoid any difficulties that may arise from the overlap in the two different timing arrangements during a financial year. The proposed amendments to the Excise Tariff Act and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Act have been developed after consultation with the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill removes LPG from the ambit of the Excise Tariff Act. At present, LPG produced from offshore fields that came into production after 17 August 1977 is excisable under this act, although the current rate of excise on LPG is `free'. This bill makes the production of LPG excise exempt by removing LPG from the ambit of the Excise Tariff Act. This will remove another unnecessary administrative burden from the producers of LPG and the government.

The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill also proposes decreases in the rate of excise duty on aviation gasoline—avgas—and aviation kerosene—avtur—of 75c per litre, with effect from 1 September 1996. The decreases in the excise duty on avgas and avtur were the result of an over‐collection of excise duty on these products during 1995‐96.

The reduction also takes account of the reduction in the operating costs of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the forecast growth in airline activity, which will lead to increases in the consumption of aviation fuels. The decreases were proposed in Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 of 1996, which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 16 September 1996 and took effect from 1 September 1996.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Broadcasting Services Legislation Amendment Bill and the cognate bills that we are dealing with today are supported by the opposition. I will explain our reasons for supporting these three pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, on the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1997 and the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1997, we believe that in many ways the current government is implementing the views of the former government and the former minister on this issue—that is, that the government is seeking to ensure that the community continues to get a return from the private use of frequencies for radio and television broadcasts.

BREAK.PARA: In Australia, certainly ever since we have had television and over the many years of the existence of radio, we have had an expectation that those companies that are awarded television and radio licences should pay an annual fee to the taxpayer as a return to the community for allowing that company the exclusive use of the scarce radio electromagnetic spectrum. One of the difficulties which arose during the time I had the honour to serve as the minister for communications was an anomaly that emerged in the Broadcasting Services Act, as originally enacted by this parliament. The anomaly was that all of the existing radio and television licence holders knew that they were up for a certain annual licence fee, but the act provided for the auctioning to new licensees of new frequencies. As the act was originally passed by the parliament, they would be auctioned, the government would get the maximum price, and those licensees would pay no licence fees.

Of course, that immediately meant that every one of the existing radio licence holders was knocking at the government's door to demand that the anomaly be removed by exempting them from having to pay annual licence fees—which would have been a massive handout to all of the existing radio and television licence holders. Given that these are some of the most profitable companies in Australia—although, admittedly, some of the people involved in the radio industry are small families in the bush and are not large companies—it would have been ridiculous to have given such a massive financial benefit to some of the largest companies in Australia.

The alternative way to overcome the anomaly was to impose the same regime on the new licence holders as has traditionally been placed on the existing radio and television licence holders, which is what the former government said it would do and what this government is now implementing; and this is one of the main reasons we are supporting the proposal which is before the committee at the moment. We think the public should continue to receive that annual payment in licence fees as some return to the community for the exclusive use of that scarce spectrum.

The Broadcasting Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 also clarifies the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Authority to inquire into on‐line services. This is as a result of some questions being raised about the excellent work that the ABA has been carrying out in investigating the regulation of on‐line services in Australia. At my request during the life of the former government, the ABA produced a report, which was tabled after the change of government, entitled Investigation into the content of on‐line services. It is quite important that we do not leave it to the Attorney‐General's Department and the Office of Film and Literature Classification to look at the issues of regulation and censorship that will inevitably arise with the development of the Internet and other proprietary on‐line services, probably through subsets of the Internet.

I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and many other members of this House welcome young children and schools being given increased access to many of these high‐tech pieces of equipment that equip them with better skills for better jobs in their future life, but there are many community concerns about some of the material to which children can easily gain access through the Internet. This has been the subject of a number of stories, some of which have exaggerated and sensationalised the threat. Many parents have quite legitimate concerns about how easy it may be for their children to look up how to make an explosive bomb from agricultural chemicals, or about how some people might use the Internet to transmit photographs involving child pornography, for example.

While most people think of the Internet these days as a mechanism for transmitting words and data, dangerous information available could include, for example, how to make a bomb. It could also be used to transmit photographs but, in the not too distant future, it will be easier for people to transmit audio signals—and, of course, video is not too far away at all. As a community, we have established quite strict categories for the regulation of film and television, and it would be quite ridiculous for us to have tough regulations on classification and censorship in film and television but to allow a whole new method of communication to develop that bypassed those regulations.

Many complex issues are raised by this, because in many ways it is impossible to regulate the Internet. Australia cannot pass laws which govern the citizens of all the other countries that are connected to the Internet. Despite the complexity, some countries have tried to regulate this and have tried to pass laws which put the onus on the Internet service provider to ensure that there is no illegal, outrageous or dangerous material available through that particular company's access to the Internet.

There was a great debate in the US Congress about how some conservative members of Congress wanted to make the Internet service providers—companies that provided access to the Internet—legally accountable for any unsavoury material that people could get access to through the Internet. I think quite rightly the US Congress, after a lot of debate, a lot of heat and I am not sure how much light, decided not to go down that path. I understand that in some countries in Europe that debate is still wending its way through their legislatures.

In Australia we have tried to make sure that there is cooperation between the federal government and the state governments on ways that we can make it an offence for people to store and misuse material they may get from the Internet. A number of charges have been laid in recent years arising from this and I think we have to see if we can come up with commonsense ways to ensure that we are doing all we can to protect Australian children without passing laws that are unenforceable or laws that try to impose legal obligations on Internet service providers that are just unworkable.

The long‐term hope for the side is that a number of the large software companies are developing software filters. I am sure that several members present would be aware of some schools that have developed their own smaller pool within the Internet which simply restricts quite severely the material that young children in a school can access on their school computer equipment, perhaps limiting their access to material that is stored on CD‐ROMs and other material. That is one way to impose some restrictions on what children at various schools can access, while also giving them the additional training and skills to use this new technology, which is welcome.

The other issue that is dealt with in the Broadcasting Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is a change to the cross‐media ownership rules. The change which is proposed in this act is something which the opposition supports. It seeks to make a minor modification to the rules in the way they affect small companies in one particular service area—Brisbane. The difficulty that has arisen in Brisbane involves Australian Provincial Newspapers, a company which owns 4KQ, one of the major radio stations in Brisbane. The company also owns the Queensland Times, which is the main daily newspaper in Ipswich.

The cross‐media ownership rules were meant to restrict common ownership between the main radio stations and the main television stations in capital cities and also in country towns. In the case of Brisbane, it was meant to restrict common ownership in the television stations, the radio stations and the main metropolitan dailies of Brisbane. It was never intended to impose some restriction on a paper as small as the Queensland Times. The fact that the legislation quite deliberately set out to ensure there was no common ownership between 4KQ and the Courier‐Mail has, because of the way the legislation is worded, had an unintended effect of saying that there cannot be common ownership between the Queensland Times and 4KQ. It has led to some quite ridiculous circumstances.

Under the legislation, the Queensland Times is included in the cross‐media ownership rules if more than 50 per cent of its circulation is within the service area of 4KQ. The company ensures that it complies with the law by distributing free of charge sufficient copies of the Queensland Times outside the 4KQ service area so that those within the area are less than that 50 per cent threshold. As a result, large quantities of newspaper and newsprint are being used for no benefit other than to ensure that the law is not breached on cross‐media ownership.

The government's proposal is quite sensible. It simply seeks to say that if a paper such as the Queensland Times has a total circulation which is less than two per cent of the total newspaper daily circulation in the city concerned, in this case Brisbane, then we do not intend to have that paper caught up in the cross-media ownership provisions. As I understand it, the circulation of the Queensland Times is about one per cent of the total Brisbane circulation so it meets that concern without any difficulty whatsoever. That minor change of cross-media ownership is something that the opposition is willing to support.

Given that the cross-media ownership rules are on the table here today, I am sure you would be surprised if I was not tempted, as a former minister, to make a few passing remarks about the tar baby which this government has attached itself too, the tar baby of the Prime Minister's attempts to water down, if not abolish, the cross-media ownership rules with all of the media speculation that this is to benefit Mr Packer's company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I interrupt briefly to say that while I would have been surprised if you were not tempted, I would be disappointed if you succumbed to the temptation to drift too far from the legislation currently being considered.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, if there is legislation dealing with these changes to the cross-media ownership laws, I think I am entitled to talk about the cross-media ownership laws.
—I am merely indicating that I want it brought back to the legislation currently being considered.

—Yes, and this legislation deals with cross-media ownership laws. Therefore, I am determined to use this occasion to say a few things about the changes which everyone else in Australia is talking about, Mr Deputy Speaker. If we cannot use this occasion in the parliament of Australia to talk about one of the most important debates taking place in our country, then there is something wrong. I know that the quality of my argument will not influence your interpretation of standing orders, I accept that, but this is an important issue that people on both sides of the Australian parliament have been raising in the media. I am sure that many people are concerned about the way this change which is before the House today affects the debate about cross-media ownership rules in general in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The legislation seeks to amend the cross-media ownership rules which were introduced in 1987. Some people try to say that, in some way, those 1987 rules were meant to punish the Fairfax group. It is true that John Fairfax, after changes in its ownership, did not comply with the cross-media ownership rules and it ended up selling off some of its media assets, as did Rupert Murdoch, and as did the Herald and Weekly Times group. That was because in those cross-media ownership rules we said that no‐one should be able to own a television station and a radio station, or a television station and a major newspaper in the same city.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, you were looking after Kerry and you were looking after Rupert!

—The interjection across the chamber was, `You were looking after Kerry and you were looking after Rupert!'. If we were looking after Mr Murdoch, why was he forced to sell his two channel 10 stations under the cross-media ownership rules? It is quite clear that those rules affected Mr Murdoch as much as it affected the Herald and Weekly Times and Fairfax.

BREAK.PARA: The important point about this legislation and the way it is seeking to change the cross-media ownership rules is that it is trying to restore the balance in the cross-media ownership rules. That is what this amendment is all about, it is to ensure that we do not have a silly example in Ipswich of the Queensland Times undermining community support for the basic principle, the principle that people like the member for Bradfield (Dr Brendan Nelson) are publicly supporting, the principle—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the member for Kennedy!

—I am pleased to hear, `And the member for Kennedy'. I hope the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith) would agree also, but we are unable to get anything out of him. I hope he supports the view that no‐one should be able to own the Launceston Examiner and the television stations in Launceston. We think that is too much power for one person to have, to own all of the media assets in Launceston.
—Except if it is him!
—`Except if it is him', he says. I am sure he would treat himself very fairly, but I am not sure about local Labor candidates.
—The member for Dobell should direct his remarks through the chair, as he knows.

—We would like to encourage the member for Bass to return to his position as the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman as soon as possible. The point I am trying to make, not picking up too many of the interjections, is that a lot of people on both sides of the House support that principle, that you should either be big in television, a prince of the screen, or be involved in newspapers, but you should not be able to have both. That is the crucial point.

BREAK.PARA: In 1991, the current Prime Minister, John Howard, actually signed a petition saying that he was opposed to any further concentration of media ownership. What gets me is that Mr Howard is now going against the position that he adopted in 1991, a position that an overwhelming majority of members of the Australian parliament had in 1991. The member for Bass at that time signed the petition. It was the view of the overwhelming majority of people in 1991 that Mr Packer should not be allowed to get control of Fairfax.

What has changed today? Why is Mr Packer advancing the arguments to allow Mr Packer to purchase the Fairfax Group? To have the cabinet of Australia sit down and work out whether the Financial Review can be carved off from the Fairfax Group, to allow the cabinet of Australia to try to redesign the media landscape is, I think, the height of impertinence. It will only advance the interests of one company, and that is Mr Packer's.

The important point I want to make is that some people are saying that we need to abolish these cross‐media ownership rules that are before the committee here today. The people, such as Mr Howard, who are saying that we need to abolish the cross‐media ownership rules are saying that in some way that means we will end up with stronger Australian companies. Mr James Packer goes around saying that this will mean that they could export the Sydney Morning Herald or the Financial Review to the rest of the world.

The problem with that theory is that Rupert Murdoch took his company to the rest of the world, and he did that from a very small base. He started in Adelaide with an afternoon newspaper, I think it was. He picked up the Daily Telegraph and the Daily Mirror in Sydney. He also had a loss‐making paper in those days called the Australian. He was able to go off and purchase newspapers in Britain and the United States and build up his global media empire. When he started investing overseas, he was much smaller than Mr Packer is today. Look at the Seven Network: it has recently made a major acquisition in the United States in MGM. Channel 7 is much smaller than Mr Packer is today. This argument that Mr Packer has to swallow more of our media assets so that he can look for opportunities offshore is completely bogus. It is an argument that I hope government members will put to the strongest possible questioning. The clear statements from Mr Stokes and others is that this is an argument that simply does not hold water.

Before I finish, I would like to say that a few of us, including the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith), have been through these debates before. The debate that took place during the last parliament was probably one of the most important decisions that the Keating Labor government made during its time in office. A loophole emerged in the cross‐media ownership rules that if people were not in control they could build up their cross‐media shareholdings. We asked the Australian Broadcasting Authority for a report on that loophole. The loophole meant that Mr Packer was able to get more than 15 per cent of Fairfax, as long as he could not be proven to be exercising control. We got independent advice from the ABA. The ABA recommended that we return to the clear number of no more than 15 per cent. That is what we did when we were challenged: we restored the strength of those cross‐media rules because they are important to Australia.

We know the pressures that are placed on governments and members when these interests are being discussed and debated. I simply say that I respect the strength and courage which has been shown by a number of members of the government who have spoken out publicly on this very important issue. I hope that, when this debate reaches a conclusion in future months, we will be able to say that, in Australia, no one person can own a television station and a major newspaper in one of our capital cities. I hope at the end of the day we can say that, in Australia, we have kept the integrity of those cross‐media ownership laws so that we have made sure that debates in Australia are still carried out and reported by a media which is as diverse as possible, given the very high concentration that we already have in Australia.

I think it is very important that we do not allow the media in Australia to get even more concentrated than it is today. It was one of the most important issues considered by the last government and it will be one of the most important issues discussed by this government. I think it will be one issue which will tell whether Mr Howard has the courage and the strength that he showed on gun ownership. It will show whether he is willing to carry that over and show some courage and strength on an issue that affects Mr Packer, and affects the way parliaments and politics are debated in Australia. It is an issue that I think is going to be very important for the future of our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking up where the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) left off, I most certainly would express my very strong opposition to any moves that would allow further concentration of media ownership in Australia. It would be hard to point out a single other country on earth where some 75 per cent of what is read and seen is owned by three people or, arguably, just two people. That is not a healthy democracy; that is a very unhealthy democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: With all due respect to the member for Dobell, I think that there was a little dodging, ducking and weaving on the issue of who was responsible for what. Both The Rise and Rise of Kerry Packer, which is a very famous book in Australia, and The Bold Riders, which is another very famous book which talks about the so‐called `corporate cowboys' of the 1980s, both delineate that the moves engineered by Mr Keating and Senator Richardson resulted in the two magnates, Mr Packer and Mr Murdoch, making over $2,000 million. The difference in the value of their shares prior to the media ownership changes and after the media ownership changes was some $2,000 million: a very cogent argument for having destroyed and torn a big hole in the democracy of Australia! I would not like to see this government walk down the same pathway. I pay tribute to the opposition spokesman, who is taking quite a courageous stand on this issue, and a very good one.

Having said those things, I would also like to pay tribute, which is called for here because we are talking about cross‐ownership today, to Margot Kingston. It took a lot of courage to take an open stand as she has done. If the ball bounces the other way, I think she will be looking for another job fairly speedily. I admire courage and integrity. In North Queensland, we have been very blessed with people of great courage and integrity in our media, and Alex Rainey, John Nutting and Kirsty Alfredson are three people who leap to my mind and are associated with the ABC. Whilst the ABC is not involved in what we are talking about today, the preservation of that institution standing upright gives a diversity of ownership that is desperately needed in this country, particularly in light of the damage that was done to democracy in this country by the previous Prime Minister. I am pleased to hear that the Labor party has supposedly changed its spots. We wonder if they would be taking the same position, if they were in office.

In speaking about these things and about licensing, I think that all of us would agree with the proposal before the House with respect to the licensing charges to television broadcasters, but I cannot speak about this issue without raising some ancillary problems that exist, and I am very pleased that the Minister representing the Minister for Communications is in the House. In one piece of monumental and almost mind‐numbing bureaucratic stupidity, not just 100 but hundreds of narrowcast licences in regional Australia were, I am told, handed out to a single person for a charge of $20 per licence.

People have tried to buy those licences, and the same person is charging—and has been paid, I am informed—many thousands of dollars for those licences. One person told me that the person said that he wanted $20,000 for the licence. It is a piece of absolutely extraordinary incompetence that anyone could have been responsible for this. You may say that we cannot redress without providing compensation, but this is such an absolutely outrageous case that the person concerned could not possibly apply for compensation if other narrowcast licences are issued over those same towns.

Where the rubber meets the road here is that regional broadcasters throughout outback Queensland would have liked to have got some of those licences so that they could put TAB services into those towns. For tiny towns of 1,000 or 2,000 people, they were being asked for $20,000 from a person who had filled out a form and put up $20. It received, I am told, most certainly over 100 of these licences throughout Australia.

That was a lovely little windfall. If we are talking about $10,000 per licence, then this person made a million dollars out of a few days work filling out the necessary forms and putting up $20 per licence. It is a most extraordinary event. The fact that it has not been rectified is beyond belief, as far as I am concerned. I refer this case to the Minister for Communications and the Arts.

On the issue of providing licences for some of these small towns, the bureaucracy controlling this area is not taking a sensible and flexible approach to the granting of these licences. With the proposal before the House that owners of radio stations now be able to have an interest in newspapers, there has to be some flexibility and sense built into the system.

That particularly applies in country Queensland where we had the ridiculous situation where none of the locally owned radio stations could get the licence to provide the TAB service to the people. We went for three years without that. When the bureaucracy eventually got around to making a decision on that, it gave the TAB of Queensland exclusive rights to that coverage, thus tearing a big hole in the little locally‐owned regional radio stations throughout Queensland. I do not think good judgment was exercised there at all.

A further issue on the subject of television is that television broadcasters pay a common fee. They pay a licence fee to the government, but really what the government has given them is a monopoly that is controlled by three people. That is an enormously powerful asset.

I would not be hypocritical enough to say that we should listen to Mr Hilmer, but it seems to me that the decision makers in this place take their riding instructions from him. It seems to me that those riding instruction are always the wrong ones—they do not take the good ones. However, if we were to take the principles of those policies seriously three people would not be given the licence to print money through the ownership of these three licences. The most common fee paid by the TV broadcasters is very low compared with the enormous benefits that flow from the three‐man ownership of this Australian monopoly.

That monopoly was produced by the decision making of the people opposite when they were in government. They stand condemned for moving towards the situation we have today where we have three networks, and regional television has almost ceased to exist in Australia. It has been destroyed. As our image of ourselves in regional Australia has been destroyed, so too has the soul of the people of regional Australia. Members opposite can take responsibility for that.

A recent survey of young people in Australia asked them to list the 20 most famous people they knew of and looked up to in Australia. Not one Australian was listed amongst the 20 people that they knew of and looked up to. That is a direct result of the networks we have that buy programs from overseas and thus project an image to these young people of overseas people. Our image of ourselves is lost completely, and with it a very large proportion of our sovereignty, and that will have disastrous consequences for all of us.

Finally, in canvassing these issues today there are two other issues that need to be addressed and I would be doing a great disservice to the people of Kennedy if I did not address them. In the western towns of Queensland, while some of those towns can pick up the satellite pay television, most of the people there have mean incomes that are so low that it would be very difficult for them to pay for pay television and the vast bulk of those towns cannot get pay television anyway. There needs to be some flexibility built into the system to allow us to take the pay television signal down to earth and relay it. There are some new technologies that will allow that but in my discussions with the licensing authority for Australia, I really have had a very large level of ignorance and a very low level of helpfulness so I would have to speak with some criticism of the officials and the department in that area.

The second issue relating to television licensing that we are discussing here today is the fact that all of those western towns in Queensland can receive channel 7 and channel 9 albeit without the advertising. There are little gaps in there and we just have a blank television screen where the advertising should be. But in places where we have very few recreational pursuits—entertainment is a better word—available to us then television becomes a very important entertainment resource to us. We have no local picture theatres, we have no theatre—not that too many people would go to theatre—we have none of those things in these country towns and yet we do have channel 9 and channel 7. The existing laws do not allow us to pick up those television broadcasts and there is just no reason or logic attached to that. There was in days past when channel 0 was up on the satellite by itself and put a very special satellite service into regional Australia. Maybe there needs to be some protection for that but really the way the situation is working at the present moment, I would find it very difficult to argue against the people's right to be able to take the channel 9 and channel 7 service that they can get right now. But they are not allowed to because of the laws that exist in Australia. A person in Brisbane is able to get the four channels but a person in Julia Creek is only able to get one channel and that is channel 0.

In days past, there was a full television crew out in Mount Isa. I do not wish to criticise channel 0 and the people that are in Mount Isa today work very hard but it is no longer a proper journalist set‐up where the journalists go all over the countryside picking up news items from western Queensland. That situation no longer exists in central Queensland or in the mid‐west of north Queensland. The arguments that existed before are not there today.

Finally, an excellent charitable institution in the state of Queensland operates in my electorate and they unfortunately got caught as one of the COT cases. When we talk about communications and fairness to everybody—as we are talking here about fairness to everybody by allowing a regional newspaper to go into towns and the television broadcaster's most common fee—we are trying to establish laws that are fair to everybody. There are some really dreadful problems in there with the big institutions. If there is any watering down of the media ownership rules and the ownership of the media becomes more centralised, we then have huge institutions that become not only unreactive but enormously oppressive. In this terrible case, it was admitted in the Senate estimates that $7 million has been spent fighting 20 or 30 of these COT cases, one of whom is a charitable institution in the state of Queensland, looking after crippled children. When institutions get big, not only do they become unreactive, but they also become oppressive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the remarks of the member for Kennedy about COT cases were wider of the bill than the member for Dobell's (Mr Lee) remarks about media ownership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It is my task to briefly sum up these three amendments. They have been agreed to by the opposition and I gave detailed second reading speeches in the chamber some time ago. We are pleased that the opposition has joined us and that these bills will go through. I might make a few remarks about some of the things that were discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Dobell (Mr Lee) talked about the issue with regard to on‐line services. That is not part of this legislative package. I want to point out to the Main Committee that the issues that he was talking about are in a piece of legislation that has been introduced into the Senate and is yet to come to this place. His remarks, all the same, were well made on access to Internet and protection. How one might limit access to some of the activities that one might find on the Internet is an issue that each member in this place would be concerned about. Most certainly, the government is and the minister is as well.

The other point that he made, and he did wander a little, was about the cross‐media ownership change in this piece of legislation that relates to an uninfluential newspaper being in the same market as a radio station. This amendment is designed to correct that position, primarily in Ipswich in Queensland, and he accepts that. He went on to make other comments about cross‐media ownership and related those back to 1987.

I have some regard for the member for Dobell. He was a former minister and did chair a rather well‐known committee into media law. His comments are noted, but he would not expect me to comment on those matters other than to say that these are issues actively being considered by the government at this time. There have been comments made by many and sundry. I am sure that will continue. That is the nature of the debate which is being held but the government, once it has fully consulted within the government and with all its members and more broadly in the community, will make a decision in the broader public interest.

The member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) made a well‐informed contribution about these matters. Some of those issues of a technical nature relating to signal access, the impact of localism and so on have been taken up by my colleagues from the department who are here. They will be able to address some of those issues more directly.

You made one point about narrowcast licensing. I was not aware of that issue. I would make the point that narrowcast licensing is somewhat qualitatively different to radio licensing in that they receive what is known as a transmitter licence from the Spectrum Management Agency and attract a cost recovery fee. I do not recall what the limitations are under the act, even though I was the one who brought it into the parliament in about 1991 on behalf of the opposition. I am sure that matter will be subject to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) reviewing some of the issues with the SMA later this year or in 1998. That matter will, I am sure, be taken up and answered to your satisfaction. I thank you for drawing that matter to our attention.
On the matter of COT cases, as a former ombudsman who was intimately involved in these matters—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did a very excellent job!

—I thank you for that kind interjection and can that be underlined. I am aware of these issues. They are very, very difficult matters. They have visited upon individuals in our country a great deal of anguish. I know that Telstra and others have been trying to cope with these matters, but I thank the member for drawing them to our attention. I do take the injunction of the Deputy Chairman that it is outside the province of this debate. Therefore, I would conclude by thanking members for their contributions. I am pleased that these bills will now proceed.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
Consideration resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Warwick Smith:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

BREAK.XREF: AUSTRALIAN ANIMAL HEALTH COUNCIL (LIVE‐STOCK INDUSTRIES) FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the opposition have already indicated to the government, we are quite comfortable with the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill. It carries through further stages of the reforms of the dairy industry which began under our administration and continues that thrust, so we have indicated that the passage of the bill will not face opposition from us.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a few observations that I would like to make in respect of the dairy industry and my colleague the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) will be following me in making some comments. It is worth pointing out that, whilst this bill provides for an increase in the levy to be paid to the Australian Animal Health Council to ensure that the AAHC and the system around it is capable of maintaining and furthering Australia's animal health standards, the legislation does not provide at this point for an increase in the levy. It simply makes it possible for the industry to apply to the government for the right to do this.

What I would say to the industry is that when it comes to the point that they are looking for an increase in the levy, and knowing full well that such an increase is accompanied by a government matching contribution—don't hold your breath. From what I have seen from the fine print of last night's budget, particularly in the allocation to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the allocations are all on the downward slope, not the upward slope.

There is one thing we will have to be cognisant of—and I put the government on notice now on this matter—if we are to proceed with the extraordinary rate of progress that has been made in this industry. I note from current statistics that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) has provided in the second reading speech that we have now reached production levels of nine billion litres of milk per year in the dairy industry and we now have exports of the order of 50 per cent of that production. Assuming that we are now in the stage where those exports are profitable, it should be remembered that when Labor's reform of the dairy industry began back in the mid‐1980s, much of Australia's export produce from the dairy industry was significantly subsidised by the domestic consumer. We have now turned that around and are on a forward path.

The key point I make about that is that the science is vital. I think that is well understood by the farm community. It is understood by government, I hope. So when it does come to the point that the industry is proposing an increase in the levy and that means, therefore, an increase in the budget allocation to that science to ensure that the Animal Health Council and the research that flows off it is available, then there should be no penny‐pinching about this on the part of the Treasurer (Mr Costello).

I want to foreshadow a concern that, given the trend of budget provisions, particularly as they affect primary industry, this does not sound as straightforward and as easy to win as we might think. So, it is on notice to the government as one of the matters we will be committing to because we want to emphasise the importance of this commitment to research and development of science in the development of the industry.

While I am speaking about the dairy industry, I could not avoid making some observations on some of the allocations in the budget announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) last night. They pertained very relevantly to people in the dairy industry. The first thing I want to make an observation about is what I call the `great savings con'. What we saw announced last night was that a previously committed and opposition guaranteed contribution to the incomes of farmers and farmworkers in the form of superannuation contributions to be made by the government, has been snatched away. And it is interesting to note that an ordinary farmworker about 30 years of age working through to age 60, be it a dairy farmworker on wages around the level that dairy farmworkers get—and we all know what they are—would have received a government contribution in the order of about $100,000. Instead, what has been offered has been snatched away—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on a matter of relevance. I wonder what this has got to do with the Dairy Produce Levy Bill.

—I thank the member for Wannon. I was listening to the comments of the member for Burke and I felt that it was at least relevant enough to be relaying his illustration to the dairy industry and I presume he is going to draw a parallel to some of the amendments that were in the bill. I was giving him that amount of tolerance.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is exactly the point. I made the point earlier before the member for Wannon arrived that the future of this industry lies around having the finance, the capital and the science to protect those developments. If you want to restrict me to a very tight discussion about the amendments of this bill and not allow me—

—I would remind the member for Burke that the member for Wannon will not be restricting him in any way at all, but the Chair may well choose to restrict him if he ranges too widely. Right now, he is speaking at the Chair's protection.

—I understand that, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I observe that the member for Wannon rose to his feet and drew this to your attention and that he has begun the process of trying to restrict these comments. Let us analyse this great savings con in its reality. The member for Corio (Mr Richard Evans) will make some further observations on this more specifically. We are talking about an industry in some parts of Australia which is facing very severe weather patterns and a food crisis at the moment. In fact, it is spending all its savings buying feed for stock that cannot now be fed. So how on earth are those people going to ever qualify for any of the Treasurer's great savings rebate? In Gippsland, they are spending $1 million a day buying in feed for their stock—
—At this point, the member for Burke must concede that we are ranging rather wider than was intended by the legislation before the Chair and I would invite him to return to the legislation.
—That may be the case, Mr Deputy Speaker—
—It is, indeed, the case.

—Let me also take on one of the aspects of this Australian Animal Health Council. I refer you to comments that the minister made in his second reading speech. He spoke correctly about the importance of dairy research and the importance of the animal health. And what are one of the key factors that relate to this importance? It is Australia's quarantine standards and the level to which we protect the dairy stock and develop it.

SPEECH.PARA: Another one of the great hoaxes presented in last night's budget and all over the press this morning is the claim that we are actually increasing funding for quarantine.

Well, yes we are. If you go to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy's budget, you will find that it has been cut. The funds are being made up from—guess where?—the world's greatest environment package. A one-off lump sum that was promised for the environment is now being milked to cover up a range of substantial funding cuts which will have to be redefended. This is the point I make. It will have to be redefended.

BREAK.PARA: Members opposite ought to understand this because their constituency, including dairy farmers who are now being asked to prepare themselves for an increase in the levy as provided for in this legislation, are now being asked to face up to the fact that the budget is being cut. At some point, new funds are going to have to be fought for and they will not be there. There is no evidence to date that anyone in the government can successfully mount a case with the Treasurer for funding for rural Australia and particularly these industries. This is going to be a pretty interesting debate as it unfolds.

About this heritage budget, where is the billion dollars coming from? It is coming from the sale of Telstra. We all know that and, what we are not saying anything about, of course, from the dispensing with 22,000 workers in Telstra as part of the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with the dairy industry?

—Order! The members for Wannon and Corangamite are not even allowing the chair to have a word to say. I would remind the member for Burke that the chair has been in fact very tolerant through this debate and has allowed a wider ranging debate than was intended by the legislation. But he is now in fact pushing the chair's tolerance to the limit. I invite him to return to the bill before the House.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The point I am making, and I am doing my best to contain it within the confines, is that this bill provides for an increase in the levy. You understand that well and I understand that well. What I am saying is, when the industry comes along wanting an increase in the levy, the bill also provides that there is a matching contribution from the government. That matching contribution is not in the budget and it is not going to be in the budget.

BREAK.PARA: I make some flow‐on points about the farmers who need this sort of support. It is clear to me that many farm families rely on off‐farm income to support them through tight times. What we are seeing is the pulling away of that off‐farm income. Where is the income that is going to provide for the increase in the levy? This is the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very confusing!

—You might say it is confusing but I can follow it very clearly. Remember that the Deputy Speaker is holding me to some very tight guidelines here in developing this thesis but I will do it in many other places, so I am not too worried about that.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, as I am making the point here, we are seeing the great savings con. We are seeing the funding of the primary industry budget off the back of a broken promise. We are seeing no prospect whatsoever of funding being available in the budget of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to support an increase in the dairy produce levy, unless the members opposite are saying to us now and to the dairy industry, `Yes, when you want it, it will be there'. It will be there by poaching more from the world's greatest environment fund or we think somehow we can win the case against the Treasurer who has been ripping the heart out of funding to rural areas.

We will explore this as we go down the track. As I said, the member for Corio and I have recently visited the region of Gippsland in Victoria and looked specifically at the dairy industry. The member for Corio will tell you about the factories that we visited and the dairy produce issues that we have looked at. Most interestingly we will be focusing on the fact that one of the ministers in your government lives right in the heart of this region and yet has not said a word about the plight of dairy farmers in his own electorate. And the National Party—
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you blokes don't care. You guys are Liberals. You don't care if the Nationals commit harakiri. What about the Victorian state minister Mr McNamara? There is no submission as yet to Canberra on behalf of the dairy farmers in this National Party region. No wonder the seat was lost!
—Order! The member for Burke knows that, once again, he is straying a long way from the bill.

—I accept that in that particular case, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I want to make the point that it is very relevant to the future of the dairy industry. The member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) will be making some very pertinent points, but I call on the government to rethink a number of things. I call on it to rethink the slashing of funds in country regions. I call on government members opposite to get in there and turn around this great savings hoax. I call on them to give the dairy farmers and their workers back their superannuation contributions, knowing that they will never have any savings to qualify for the great savings hoax. The only people who have money to qualify for the great savings hoax in the farm sector are the corporates.

BREAK.PARA: To sum up, the opposition is perfectly relaxed with this legislation in the form that it is in, but I foreshadow to the dairy industry and to members opposite that I can see very clearly that we are providing for the industry to apply for an increase in the levy. The levy is vital to the science behind the research on the future wellbeing of the dairy herd in Australia—there is no question about that.
