However, the hook behind all this is that, under current arrangements, there is a dollar for dollar subsidy off‐budget for any increase in the levy. When the industry comes to seek that, on all the evidence in front of us at the moment, do not hold your breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and I must admit that I found his speech totally confusing and his logic convoluted. I can understand why he is part of the opposition. If the only contribution he can make to this debate is to make spurious claims about things that really do not make much sense, then I guess he will spend a long time in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill, I endorse the words of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). He talked about the importance of this levy and the importance of ensuring that Australia's animal health service system is capable of maintaining acceptable national animal health standards which meet both consumer needs and market requirements in domestic and international markets. As he went on to point out, the Animal Health Service is jointly funded and jointly owned by the states and the Commonwealth government.

This bill is about raising the ceiling on the amount of levy that can be charged on the dairy industry. It is not actually about raising the levy per se, but it does recognise that the current level of levy is very close to the previous maximum research levy rate and, therefore, it is important to allow that flexibility and scope for an industry that chooses to increase its contribution to research to be able to do so.

I was amazed by the extraordinary insinuations that the member for Burke came up with, suggesting that, if the dairy industry actually increased its contributions, he was not sure that the government would match it. That is a load of nonsense. He then went on with some convoluted logic about finding the money from part of the budget, but not the part of the budget that he said it should find it from. Again, that seems to be utter nonsense. Really, we expected better from him in his contribution to this debate.

I would also make some reference in passing to the fact that the member for Burke made another extraordinary claim about the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) by saying that he had made no comment about the current seasonal difficulties that are facing dairy farmers in his region. I can say that I happened to hear on the radio in the last couple of weeks the member for Gippsland drawing attention to that very fact. I suggest to the member for Burke that he ought to do a bit more research and that he ought to do his homework instead of coming in here and making absolutely nonsensical statements which only go to show one thing: how totally ignorant he is about the whole issue.

The other point that we ought to draw attention to is that in last night's budget there was a tremendous announcement about the whole question of quarantine and the contribution that the Commonwealth is making to quarantine. This very much reinforces the government's commitment to the dairy industry, because we all know how important it is to have a really first class quarantine service that will in fact ensure that, when we talk about animal health and about reaping the benefits of the research from such things as the dairy produce levy, they do not in fact get lost because we have not maintained the world's best quarantine standards.

That contribution is very welcome. It is a very big plus and it shows, most significantly, that we have a government that recognises how important it is in primary industries—and the dairy industry in particular—to ensure that we do maintain very high standards. I commend the minister for that initiative. I believe that it shows again that the government is very much in touch with the needs of the dairy industry and also very much recognises that we have to maintain the highest standards possible and not allow industries such as the dairy industry to risk the importation of some disease that could put at risk not only our domestic consumers but also our very significant export markets.

I will now take up some of the issues that the minister talked about in his second reading speech. He spoke about the significant growth in recent years in the dairy industry, with milk production in the current financial year expected to exceed nine billion litres for the first time on record, which is a tremendous achievement. But, as he pointed out, half of this production will be exported, with the value of exports expected to be about $1.8 billion. That is a fantastic achievement.

I will expand on those comments of the minister and talk about them from the local perspective of, in particular, the south‐west area of Victoria—which I have the great honour to represent and which is also shared by my colleague and good friend the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). What we have seen in the dairy industry in the south‐west corner of Victoria is enormous changes over the past 80 years, and what we are now looking at is a very significant industry that makes very significant contributions not only to the economy of Victoria but also to the economy of Australia.

The Victorian dairy industry is now producing about 62 per cent of Australia's milk; but, better and more significant than that, is the fact that it is also producing about 85 per cent of Australia's dairy exports. The Victorian dairy industry is the state's largest decentralised industry, adding about $5 billion to the economy. As I have pointed out already, Victoria is the largest dairying state. We have more dairy farmers, more dairy cows, more milk produced and more butter, cheese and milk powder manufactured than in all other states combined. In fact, the south‐west diary industry, which is just one part of Victoria, is larger than the combined dairy industries of Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania, and the flow‐on benefits to local industries and to the local economy are enormous. But not only that: it is a very efficient industry. As the Boston Consulting Group found in 1993, our dairy industry is among the producers of lowest‐cost milk, by world standards, and we rank alongside New Zealand.

Furthermore, the contribution that dairy farmers make to the community is very significant. The average farmer spends around $2,400 a week on farm input and services. This has a major impact in a local community. The growth that has been achieved by farmers in the region is very impressive. Over the last 10 years, Victorian dairy herds have increased almost 40 per cent to average 143 cows per dairy. They are forecast to average around 200 cows in four to five years time. These are fantastic achievements. This is fantastic growth.

The other thing to note about the dairy industry in Australia is that the production per cow over the last 25 years has literally doubled. I listened to an eminent scientist talking about this who went on to suggest that not only has that been achieved; there is also an expectation that production will double again over the next 25 years. It really is an industry that has a very proud record of achievement.

It is also significant to note the input to the local community. For every 100 jobs in the dairy industry, there are another 110 created in associated activities. To put it another way, for every dollar of farm output, there is another $2.80 worth of goods and services created as a result of dairy processing and associated activities. As a result, in the south‐west region of Victoria, the dairy industry is responsible for the employment of around 10,000 people. South‐west Victoria produces around 30 per cent of Victoria's milk from around 2,000 herds and under 400,000 cows.

The other thing to note is the sheer size of investment in the region. This is an industry of great significance, but also an industry of confidence. Recently we have seen Bonlac spend $50 million at Cobden in my electorate. We have seen Murray‐Goulburn spend $35 million at Koroit in my electorate. Warrnambool Cheese and Butter is spending around $50 million over five years in their expansion. Nestle, also in Warrnambool, is undergoing a $30 million expansion. These are big investments and they show that this industry has significant confidence and is a major contributor, not only to my region of the state of Victoria, but also to the whole state and, indeed, to the whole nation.

The clean and green reputation of this region puts the local dairy industry in a prime position to make the most of opportunities in the increasing export demand in Asia. It is worth noting just how significant this export demand is. As the Asian region becomes more affluent and seeks alternatives, such as more dairy products, we are seeing that the opportunities are enormous. For example, while the average Japanese currently eats 1½ kilograms of cheese per year, this is expected to increase to 2½ kilograms by the year 2000. That will mean an additional 120,000 tonnes in exports and it is obvious that much of this will come from Victoria.

The other thing to pay tribute to is the dairy community, which has shown that it can respond to challenges. These people are not waiting for it to happen; they are working to make it happen. We have seen the challenges that will be there for the future. We obviously have to continue to seek new export markets and that is being done. We still have to deal, as a national government, with attacking some of the problems of the incentive programs—as they are called by other countries, such as the United States—and how we can best make sure that, through the World Trade Organisation, our dairy farmers are not disadvantaged by some of the trade barriers that still exist in the world.

Nonetheless, if you look at our share of the world dairy trade, it has more than tripled since the 1980s. It has gone from three per cent to 10 per cent. It is quite an impressive record. In fact, I would suggest it is an extremely impressive record and one that all Australians ought to be made more aware of.

Interestingly, despite all the opportunities in Asia, if the Australian dairy industry continues to increase at its current rate, our market share in Asia will actually decline. In other words, while we are continuing to improve our performance and the volume and value of our exports, the opportunities are so great that we are going to have difficulty in meeting those opportunities.

Another thing to note about the region is that in 1977 there were 8,500 dairy farms in the region. Twenty years later—this year—that figure has dropped by around 6,000 but, despite this, productivity has continued to increase by about three per cent per year. I think it is also worth looking at some of the ways that the industry has not only made these great strides but is continuing to do so.

If we look, for example, at some of the ways that the south‐west is positioning itself for the 21st century we will see a number of things that I think are very impressive. For example, under the property management planning funding we will see local farmsmart coordinators being appointed. They will work with the dairy farmers and with risk managers to look at the best ways of risk management to cope with some of the unavoidable seasonal difficulties. This is the positive way that the local dairy farmers are setting about to look at some of the difficulties that the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) seemed to want to dwell on so much. Rather than taking his negative, pessimistic view, they are looking forward and taking a positive approach to see how they can better improve their lot and manage those sorts of risks.

We have the WestVic Dairy, which has several projects running looking at both the scientific and the human side of the industry. We have seven Focus Farms up and running between Swan Marsh and across to Mount Gambier in South Australia, and the information that is gained from these farms is being transferred through support farmers and to the communities. We have the Target 10 program, which is all about increasing pasture productivity and optimising pasture development—again a very significant project. We have the farmsmart program and we also have the Demo Dairy which was recently set up just outside Terang. That is another example of just how the dairy industry can in fact ensure itself that it is doing the very things that are needed to improve the productivity and consolidate the position of the dairy industry in the region.

As well as that, there has been an enormous amount of work undertaken by the United Dairy Farmers of Victoria, the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, the WestVic Dairy—as I mentioned—and Glenormiston Agricultural College and the South West College of TAFE are in the region. All of these factors are ensuring that we have a strong, vibrant, healthy, growing industry that is taking up the challenges of the future and is not sitting back saying `Look what we have achieved so far' because they recognise that they have to continue.

One of the interesting spin‐offs, or side developments, is the Acme field days. Here again is an example of this region taking up the challenge in the dairy industry and building a very successful field day. It only started 15 years ago and has gone from 20 exhibits in the first year to 450 this year. I was very proud to have the opportunity to open these field days because I think they are one of the highlights of the agricultural agenda of the year in my region. From around 600 visitors in the first year the number now exceeds 20,000 at the field days—it is now the biggest dairy field day in Australia and is also recognised internationally.

These are the sorts of achievements that have been going on in my region. I cannot overlook the achievements of the Warrnambool cheese and butter factory itself, a cooperative that has been extremely successful and has moved with the times. As I mentioned earlier, it is in the process of undergoing a $50 million expansion. Some of that has already been done but in five years that is a tremendous achievement. The Warrnambool cheese and butter factory began in 1888 and it has expanded every year. The new expansion that it has just announced is going to serve 600 suppliers. That is an example of a cooperative that can actually make sure that it is not only in tune with today's needs but is planning for the future.

I think the dairy industry in my region, in fact in Australia, is an industry that has been one of the quiet achievers in the Australian economy. It has been a quiet achiever because it is made up of people who want to get on and make the future happen rather than just letting it happen. Therefore this bill, which allows the opportunity for the industry to increase its efforts into research, is to be commended. It quite clearly shows that the dairy industry has recognised the value of the research which, of course, is matched on a dollar for dollar basis by the Commonwealth government, and it recognises the importance of increasing that effort.

Most importantly, it recognises that if an industry is to be able to continue to be competitive and to expand into markets in Asia, in particular, and elsewhere, it has to have access to the best research it can afford. I commend the industry for being forward looking in this. I believe that its contribution to the Australian economy will continue to grow. Most significantly, I believe that the south‐west dairy region of Victoria—in my electorate—is going to continue to be a leader in the dairy industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition's position on the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1997 has been explained to this House by the shadow minister for primary industries, the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). Let me reiterate the introductory remarks in the explanatory memorandum that the purpose of this bill is to establish a statutory levy mechanism to fund the dairy industry's contribution to the Australian Animal Health Council and to double the maximum research levy rate specified in the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act of 1986. The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill of 1997 establishes a new levy—the Australian Animal Health Council levy—which is to be imposed on milk producers to fund the dairy industry's contribution to the Australian Animal Health Council.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to comment in too much detail about this particular levy but suffice it to say that I reiterate the remarks made by the shadow primary industries minister in this debate. If I were a dairy farmer of this nation, I would not hold my breath about the contribution of the existing government to this particular levy fund, if it is called on to do so. I would like to take up some of the remarks that have been made in this debate by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), and no doubt the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) will be following with some similar remarks.

Let me just state, for the rural Liberals who are present in the chamber today, that the health and prosperity of the dairy industry, as enunciated here by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wannon, are due not only to the efforts of those in the farm sector and in the dairy industry itself—and I commend the dairy farmers for their skill and enterprise in lifting their industry to be the jewel in the crown, if you like, of Australian rural industry—but also to the foresight and vision of Labor primary industry ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one!

—Dairy farmers throughout the length and breadth of this country will tell you that it was the Kerin plan that set up the prosperity of the Australian dairy industry, followed by the Crean plan, and supplemented by the measures of Labor governments. Those are the things that have propelled this industry to the forefront of rural industry in this nation today. I can understand that the sheep man over there, the honourable member for Corangamite—I stood against him in 1984 for the seat of Corangamite—is a bit testy on this.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give you a bit of history, Mr Deputy Speaker. In the 1984 campaign, John Kerin and I went into the Heytesbury settlement, which was then in the electorate of Corangamite but is now in the electorate of the honourable member for Wannon. We went to a meeting of dairy farmers in the Heytesbury shire hall. They had been stirred up by the honourable member for Corangamite and his cohorts in the Liberal Party. Indeed, if they had had a rope there that day, they probably would have hanged us.

We delivered a fairly blunt message to them but it was a visionary message and one that has set the industry up for the prosperity that it enjoys today. We simply said to them, `We don't like the fact that over the next 10 to 15 years many dairy farmers are going to be restructured out of this industry. But there is a window of opportunity and you have to restructure and prepare yourself for the competition that is going to come from New Zealand and from the changes that are going to occur in the domestic and the international marketing environments.' We were opposed at that time bitterly by the honourable member for Corangamite and his cohorts, the rural Liberals, throughout the length and breadth of Victoria. If we had not had the vision, the political commitment and the will to restructure this industry, the prosperity that it enjoys today would simply not be there.

Those are the facts of the matter. Looking at 13 years of Labor government, not only did we introduce the great plans that restructured and repositioned this industry for the prosperity that it enjoys today, but we were the government that opened up the international marketplace where previous coalition administrations had failed miserably. We were the government that provided the labour market assistance programs that saw 1,000 dairy industry traineeships raised under the Working Nation program. It is the present government which has taken that away from the dairy industry in Victoria and the dairy industry in Australia.

The honourable member for Wannon has the temerity and the gall, if I might be so presumptuous—without going outside the bounds of propriety in this debate—to mention the Demo Dairy. The Demo Dairy in his electorate was funded under the regional development program that was abolished by the Howard government in its first budget. The one initiative that he stands up for in this particular chamber, where he says to the dairy farmers of Australia, `What a magnificent initiative this is,' we funded in the previous Labor government. His government abolished the very scheme under which we funded it.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good dairy farmer, too.

—Don't you, member for Corangamite, as an old sheep man from the Western District, come and tell me about your great interest in the dairy farmers of your particular constituency. We knew all about that in 1984 when you opposed the very measures that have now brought the industry to the prosperity that it enjoys. You opposed it bitterly. You stirred the farmers up at that particular time against the government of the day that was trying to put a plan in place to guarantee the prosperity of those farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: So when you get up to speak about how good this industry is and how important it is to the Victorian economy, how important it is to the regions of Australia and how significant it is to the export effort, at least have the decency to say that it was a Labor government that put the industry plan in place. Have the humility for once in your political life to get up in this place and say, `I was wrong; I was wrong to oppose the plan at the time; I was wrong to stir up the dairy farmers in the Western District against the candidate for Corangamite'—me at the time—`and the then Labor minister, John Kerin.'

As I said to you, we were lucky to get out of Heytesbury alive at that time. It was due in no small part to the way we persuasively argued to the dairy farmers that it was in their interests to come on board with us and not listen to the prophets of doom floating around the Western District at that time. I hope the honourable member for Corangamite, who is in this chamber, does take my advice and get on his feet today to congratulate me and, of course, the then minister, John Kerin, for the excellent plans that we had, and then have the humility to say, `I was wrong.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Corangamite will have his opportunity.

—I agree with what is being said by the honourable member for Wannon and no doubt it will be reiterated by the honourable member for Corangamite. The dairy industry is one of the brighter spots in the rural production landscape.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an industry which has undergone significant adjustment over the past 20 or 30 years. The farms are fewer, and the farmers are fewer, but the farms are producing more milk than they did in the 1970s. That structural adjustment has resulted from the introduction of new technologies and reduced levels of assistance over time that have forced the industry into looking for greater efficiencies and greater productivities. Those structural adjustments have been brought about also by changes in domestic and international marketing environments.

I come to this position with personal experience as the son of a dairy farmer in the Western District who knows quite intimately the process of structural adjustment that has occurred in this industry over time.

I can recall past days—as does the honourable member for Corangamite; we were reminiscing over in the corner. He is a sheep man now but he assures me that in his younger days he did the same thing as I did—milked the cows by hand. The herds were small, the farms were small and the output was delivered to the factories in cans. The production of fodder on farms was done by a lot of labour associated with that dairy farming operation.

In my father's day and in my day on the farm in the Western District, the great technological innovation was milking machines. The government of the day, which was a Liberal government, actually gave a subsidy to dairy farmers to put in stainless steel vats to assist in the storage of milk on farms before its collection. Times have changed. If you go to a dairy farm today there is massive capital investment in new technologies.

On the particular area in which our farm was situated, the surrounding farms have been amalgamated into one farm and a rotolactor dairy now milks around 350 cows in an irrigated farm operation which is extremely productive. If you look at the production of fodder on farm, you will see that a lot of that can be done now by one or two people with the fodder being stored in round bales on the farm and being produced with heavy equipment. Times have really changed in this industry and massive increases in productivity have come with the changes.

If we look at the outlook for the industry, generally it is projected to expand over the medium term in response to rising world demand, especially in South‐East Asia. The outlook for the industry comes off the back of the improved skills of dairy farmers and it comes off the back of improved herds and breeding programs and the introduction of new capital equipment.

As far as the manufactured milk sector is concerned, there is a positive outlook in that sector. Growth in milk production, which has been alluded to already in the debate, will be used mainly in the manufacture of butter, cheese, milk products, milk powders and other milk products. Unfortunately, the sales of market milk are not forecast to rise dramatically, but the big growth will be in the sales of manufactured milk and in the export of cheeses and other milk powders.

We look also to the spectacular exporting performance of this industry. We note also that exports are expected to rise in the medium to longer term. That reflects the increase in production which has taken place in the dairy industry today, the relatively small demand that will be generated in the domestic market and, more particularly, the spectacular growth which is predicted in the South‐East Asian market for manufactured milk products.
The important impact the dairying industry has on key regional areas in Australia and in my state of Victoria has already been alluded to in this debate.

The dairy industry does provide direct employment on farms. It is a source of extensive value added employment in country areas in the Western District, Gippsland and Goulburn Valley, with the great manufacturing production cooperatives and, of course, it is an important source of private investment. We have seen the trend to small value adding on farms. I was at the recent alternative farm vision expo in Geelong and one of the winners in that expo was a small concern producing specialty cheeses.

But the industry faces challenging external conditions in the longer term. It still faces heavy competition from New Zealand, from the policies of the European Union with its heavily subsidised cheese exports, and from the US farm support programs which provide subsidised exports into our traditional markets.

The member for Burke alluded to the fact that he and I had recently visited a very important dairy production area in Gippsland in the state of Victoria. We met with local farm representatives in the Morwell area who have been experiencing severe drought conditions. They have experienced abnormal rain patterns and this has meant that farmers have not been able to harvest fodder on farms, fodder stocks in the region are nearly exhausted and external sources of fodder are drying up as well.

I gave a commitment to the dairy farmers of that area that I would raise this matter on the floor of the parliament to see if we could excite the interest of the federal minister, as the state minister for agriculture had not even paid the dairy farmers of Gippsland the courtesy of visiting there in a time of desperate need for them.

Some farmers in the Gippsland region are spending upwards of $1,000 a day to maintain fodder supplies for their herds and they are going into debt to do this. The herds in the area are in danger as a result of the climatic conditions that have existed there and the situation will not really be improved by the breaking of the drought. The existing provisions of the national drought policy do not permit the exceptional circumstance provisions of the scheme to be brought to bear in the case of the Gippsland farmers. There is, however, a strong case for assistance to be provided on the basis of the severity of the crisis that these dairy farmers are facing and the rare climatic circumstances that have prevailed up to this time. Despite the recent rains, the problems for these farmers still exist.

The effects of this situation have been heavy financial burdens falling on dairy farmers in that region and a rundown in the quality of their herds. Sharefarmers have walked off properties and rural businesses in the Gippsland towns have been affected. As a result, there is a severe adverse regional economic impact pending in the Gippsland area.

So I mention that in the hope that the Victorian agriculture minister takes another look at the plight being faced by the Gippsland dairy farmers and, perhaps with the federal minister, engage in some discussions as to how the plight of these farmers, and others who face rare and exceptional circumstances, can be accommodated within the ambit of the national drought scheme.

Last week I visited the Goulburn Valley and met with a local UDV representative, Alan Burgess, and I discussed with him a range of issues related to dairy farmers in his region. Those matters ranged across features of local production; competition in the manufactured milk sector in the region; the recent anthrax outbreak in the Goulburn Valley; the supply of quality water for manufacturing milk production; health and education issues affecting farmers; research and development funding, and the need to constantly work on improvement to costs.

But, most interestingly, what featured in our discussion was the manner in which the dairy industry in Victoria had utilised labour market programs under the previous Labor government. They had raised 1,000 dairy industry traineeships in the past three years. The industry has recognised the importance of having a stream of skilled young people coming into the industry and assisting in its productivity improvements.

These positions were abolished, as I mentioned earlier, by the first Howard budget when it cut $1.8 billion from labour market programs, and it has cut further labour market assistance in the current budget. I will not dwell on the matters in the budget that will affect the dairy farmers because the Deputy Speaker who sat in the chair previously did get a bit testy when these issues were raised.

I will return once again to the basic proposition that I started with, that coalition members get up in this parliament and talk till they are blue in the face about what a great economic state this industry is in and what a magnificent contribution it makes to the Victorian regional economy, to the national economy and to the national export effort. The member for Corangamite, do yourself and your party and the parliament the courtesy of getting up now and acknowledging the plans that were implemented by Labor governments that have brought prosperity to this industry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this cognate debate on the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill and the Australian Animal Health Council (Live-stock Industries) Funding Amendment Bill. However, before the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) leaves the chamber, he might listen to what I have to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I am delighted that the member for Corio could take the shadow minister to Gippsland and show him a real live dairy farm so that the shadow minister might understand the industry. At least I will concede the point that the member for Corio understands the industry, having been brought up in it, having participated in it in his early years, having grown onions and having been part of a very fertile farm at Alvie, near Colac. We are delighted that the member for Corio, who has no dairy farmers in his electorate, has been good enough to take the shadow minister to see the real and genuine conditions of the dairy industry.

The second point I would like to put on the record is that I broadly agreed with the Kerin plan and I refute the claim by the member for Corio that I was against it. I draw to his attention the fact that whilst he was lucky to get out alive from the Heytesbury shire hall at his meeting with Minister Kerin, I likewise was lucky to get out alive on two occasions in the Colac hall after meetings with the UDV. Some of the views presented there were very strongly held by members of the UDV and dairy farmers in that region.

For the record, the Kerin plan basically had the concept correct. The plan was that the dairy industry should export to those markets that provided a competitive price and that the fresh milk market was no longer the be all and end all of the dairy industry. Like the member for Corio, I battled long and hard to bring about a better export focus for the dairy industry. I have said on the public record that I agreed with the Kerin plan and, in general, I fought a battle with members of the UDV at that time as they campaigned to maintain a protected domestic market.

The member for Corio would recall those arguments quite well. Mr Kerin fought a lengthy battle, particularly with the state of Victoria and with those farmers who wished to maintain the fresh milk market premium rather than sell on the overseas market, which at that time was not all that lucrative. I refute the claim that I did not support the Kerin plan. I have put on the record my support for the Kerin plan and its eventual outcome.

However, I draw a distinction between Mr Kerin and the member for Hotham (Mr Crean). The member for Hotham considered himself to be an outward looking minister in the previous government but has had a turnaround on the tariff debate in recent times. The member for Hotham has completely changed his former free trading approach to the dairy industry, the TCF industry and the car industry. He has been converted to an internal, high wall tariff supporter when formerly he was very strongly supporting lowering the tariff position.

I ask the member for Corio to get himself on the record as to where he stands on these issues since he is so clearly a free-trader for the dairy industry, an industry that has to meet world market conditions—the uneven playing field of the EC producers, the uneven playing field of the Canadian producers, and the uneven playing field of the American producers who are supported by the USA taxpayers.

I acknowledge that the member for Corio does know something about the dairy industry, unlike the shadow minister. At least the member for Corio has some hands‐on experience. I accept the view that seasonal conditions are difficult in Gippsland, but I am not sure that the former government or the current government could bring about a change in rainfall in Gippsland or in western Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —It rained the night I left.

—That was all your good work, was it? I am delighted to hear that you have such a major influence on the outcome of the dairy industry in Gippsland. This bill imposes a levy on dairy producers to fund the dairy industry's contribution to the Australian Animal Health Council. It doubles the maximum research levy, which may be set to fund the activities of the Dairy Research and Development Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Animal Health Council is a positive development in the formation of a national body to oversee animal health policy around Australia. As other members have mentioned, the recent anthrax outbreaks in northern Victoria highlight the need for a strong emphasis on animal health issues, especially for Australia, which has traditionally benefited from a clean, green, disease free image. We need to defend this image and make sure we have a national policy to maintain this island as genuinely disease free, in most cases, in our animal industries.

While the hands‐on management of the disease outbreaks remains with state governments and health authorities, the Australian Animal Health Council now exists as a national policy coordinating role. I again commend that conceptual arrangement. The council is an unlisted public company, formed on 18 August 1995 by a meeting of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand.

Again, I commend the attitude that it is a commercial organisation, funded in a commercial way with commercial objectives. It has a broad role to advise the industry and the government on animal health issues, to develop and maintain a national animal health information system, and to develop and manage animal health programs around Australia. Previously, as I have said, there was no national animal health body to advise and assist the Australian animal health service system to maintain acceptable national health standards.

The membership of the Australian Animal Health Council is comprised of the Commonwealth government, state and territory governments and industry bodies. All livestock and animal related primary industries have agreed to contribute to the funding of the organisation. I list them for the record. They are: the Chicken Meat Federation, the Egg Industry Association, the Dairy Farmers Federation, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Pork Council of Australia, the Sheep Meat Council of Australia, the Australian Horse Council and the Wool Council of Australia. Many members of the House would have had some association with those particular groups in relation to animal health problems and some of their policies with regard to imports and exports.

It was agreed that the various industries would contribute to the Animal Health Council roughly in proportion to the numbers of livestock for which they are responsible. Up until now, the dairy industry has funded its contribution through reserves, but the industry felt that in the future the most effective way to fund its contribution was through a transparent levy on producers. I think this is an acceptable way to go, that research and development and animal health issues are funded in this way for the general good of the industry. The resolution passed by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation states:
The dairy industry should fund its contribution to the cost of financing AAHC by a levy on all farmers which would be similar to a levy applied to all farmers to operate EXANDIS—
this was the forerunner to the AAHC—
prior to its determination on June 30th 1995.

The amount of the levy on dairy farmers will be modest. Again, I think that is important. There is always a tendency for these levies to rise. It has been estimated by the Australian Dairy Industry Council that the average dairy farmer will pay about $20 per year towards the council. Again, I support that general concept that this would be a small amount for each dairy farmer to pay to maintain a disease free status here in Australia.

The second part of the bill relates to the doubling of the maximum research levy which may be prescribed. The money raised by the research levy on the dairy corporation goes to the Dairy Research and Development Corporation for the purpose of conducting R&D for the benefit of the industry as a whole.

The maximum of the levy at present is 2.3c per kilogram, milk, butterfat equivalent. It had been set at or near the rate for some three or four years at the industry's request that the maximum rate be raised. Again, the industry has made the request rather than the government. There is now a realisation that we have reached a ceiling and if the Dairy Research and Development Corporation is to respond to the needs of the industry in the future, the levy must be increased modestly. The industry has requested the levy be increased so the initiative comes from the representatives of farmers and the processors themselves—again not from the government. It is important to realise that, although the maximum allowable rate of levy will be doubled, the actual levy charge will rise only slightly.

I have here a letter from the Chief Executive Officer of the Dairy Industry Council, Helen Dornom, to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, dated 19 June 1996, which sets out the case for the increase. She says in that letter:
The Australian Dairy Industry Council seeks a change in the maximum Research Levy . . .
She goes on to say:
The ADIC has agreed to increase the legislative maxima to the equivalent of 5 cents per kg milkfat.

Whilst recommending the change to the maximum, the ADIC is not at this stage foreshadowing an increase in the research levy, but simply allowing for an increase over and above the 1996‐97 research levy. According to the Australian Dairy Industry Council, they would like the levy to be set at 2.9c per kilogram, that equivalent a modest rise but one which is necessary if the Dairy Research and Development Corporation is to continue its good work. Apart from the market support levy, the research levy is the most significant paid by dairy farmers. They also pay a promotion levy for generic and domestic and overseas promotion and a corporation levy which goes to fund the Australian Dairy Corporation. These levies are considerably smaller than the research levy of 2.3c per kilogram of milk fat equivalent.

Whilst I have had some reservations about promotion levies, statutory marketing arrangements and all those things—the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) would understand—I do think there is a case for the industry providing resources to protect its disease free status and encourage further research in the whole area of animal welfare and animal disease control, especially in view of the export potential from the dairy industry.

I just add to the remarks of my good friend and colleague the member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) who made some observations about the dairy industry in western Victoria, which is really a very important part of the dairy industry of Australia, with respect to my colleague from Lyne. I think we provide about half the dairy product from Australia and, over the last two decades, there have been quite remarkable changes in the way in which the dairy industry has been structured. We had some interchange with the member for Corio about the attitude of the industry in relation to the Kerin plan and there is an emphasis on the dairy industry now being an export industry with the capacity to provide very good returns to those producers without relying on the fresh milk market.

BREAK.PARA: I am reliant on the Outlook Conference of 1996 for material that I will use to make some broader observations on the industry. The number of farmers have halved over the last two decades. The number of cows are down 20 per cent and, of course, with the introduction of supplementary feeding and improved genetics, the dairy industry has improved quite remarkably. Australia and New Zealand are low cost countries in terms of production and compete very favourably with every other country around the world.

One of the significant things that people tend to overlook is that we do not have the problem of a northern winter where the dairy cattle are housed for three months. Our dairy cattle have free range conditions and I think that gives us a tremendous comparative advantage and a big international comparative advantage in our ability to sell the product competitively. So Australia and New Zealand now move into the demand and supply position in terms of milk products around the world. The free trade rules under GATT and the Uruguay Round introduced in 1995 have provided that there are reductions of subsidies in northern America and in Europe, so Australian dairy farmers are now, under the Kerin plan which I acknowledge, able to compete favourably on the world market without the unlevel playing field subsidised by taxpayers in Europe and taxpayers in northern America.

I make the observation that the dairy industry is competing on the world markets, handling the ups and downs of the price which just in recent months has dropped a little bit although long‐term expectations are encouraging. I draw the obvious comparison of this industry in the electorate of the member for Lyons (Mr Adams), in my electorate, the electorate of Wannon and in Gippsland in Victoria where they are competing on the world market, no matter what, with the automobile industry which still enjoys a tariff protection of 22 per cent and the TCF industries which enjoy protection levels of 37 per cent and are protected from the vicissitudes of international trade.

I note the comment of the member for Wannon when he was talking about the total production of nine billion litres of milk. That is a far cry from the restrictive attitudes of policy makers that we would only produce five billion litres of milk in Australia if we did not export. The attitude was that we would supply the domestic market and if we managed to do that at a profitable rate, then we would move to the export market if it suited us. The changes that have been brought about by the Hilmer competitive arrangements in terms of fresh milk again have contributed to that. This debate was going on during the 1980s when fresh milk was sold at a regulated price. Now there is a movement by all state authorities under the Hilmer competition policy that the fresh milk price will tend to be regulated over the next three or four years and will be integrated into an export price.

Certainly the liberalised trade, as I say, around the world has ensured that the dairy farmers are meeting the expectations of markets in Asia. They are getting profits out of this expanding market of South Korea, of Japan and of other emerging Asian nations that have the capacity to buy these dairy products. That is a far cry from a domestically orientated market industry that concentrated purely on the high profit fresh milk market of Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane, and Adelaide to a lesser degree. It now has an export industry based in the electorates of Wannon, Corangamite, Gippsland and in the seat of Murray. Of course the other states provide, broadly speaking, milk product for the domestic population with some export markets.

I think the dairy industry is a great example of an industry that has made some fundamental changes, reinvested in the processing facilities, utilised the grain feeding and supplementary feeding of their animals, improved production through increased genetics, been prepared to make changes and been prepared to meet export market requirements in terms of quality and price. From a situation in the early 1980s where the arguments and the orientation were for maintaining a domestic market focus, they have now moved to be a very profitable export industry providing export earnings on the world market for Australian farmers and Australian consumers.

I commend the bill especially in terms of its general philosophic thrust to maintain the quality of health, the quality of hygiene and the quality of research that needs to be maintained in animal industries across the board and in particular, in the dairy industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to be able to participate in debates in the federal parliament of Australia revolving around the activities of the dairy industry and particularly in terms of some of the progressive attitudes that prevail in the dairy industry today and have done for some time. This bill before the House is a clear indication again of the progressive attitude that is prevalent right throughout the dairy industry today. That attitude has certainly been a key factor over recent years in developing the dairy industry into what it is today.

SPEECH.PARA: Just before I touch on a few elements of the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Amendment Bill, I want to make some comments about the contribution from the last opposition speaker, the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor). He made reference to the fact that, whenever legislation about the dairy industry is being debated in this place, members of the coalition, particularly members of the National Party, are always in here crowing about what a great industry it is. Of course, we are in here crowing about what a great industry it is. The former member for Murray and shadow minister for primary industry, Bruce Lloyd, represented an area in Victoria that has probably more dairy farmers in it than what there are in New South Wales. It is a very important industry to our constituency.

He also made reference to the fact that it was originally the Kerin plan that started the metamorphosis, I suppose, in developing the dairy industry into the successful industry it is today. He is correct again. We have never argued that or disputed that. We have supported it. At the end of the first I think it was seven years of the Kerin plan, when it was being renegotiated—I think the then minister for primary industries may have been the member for Hotham (Mr Crean)—it was supported—

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not understand it, did he?

—He did not understand the industry but, again, the coalition supported it. It is one of those things that we see from time to time and we are desperately trying to get other industries to get their focus in the same direction. The dairy industry, pre the Kerin plan era, was inward looking. They produced milk for the city markets, the market milk, as it is called. If there was a bit left over, they did a bit of processing and tried to export where there was a bit of an export market. They have now changed the focus to target those export markets.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not involved in this place in those days but I was working in an industry in my local area where we have a large and vibrant healthy dairy industry. Notwithstanding the fact that the Victorians have stolen one of our processing plants—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is efficiency.

—No, it has nothing to do with efficiency. That in itself is an indication of the future for this industry. I do not know how much help there has been from the Premier of Victoria but that plant is being replaced with a brand new plant on a greenfield site in Victoria. The point I want to make is that the industry is continually looking forward. It is looking to improve itself, and looking to better production techniques to improve efficiency and gain better access into those export markets, without the assistance or protection of some of the more corrupt initiatives of some of our competitors. I instance the US here and the dairy export incentive program that it had from time to time. There are also the current arrangements under the CAP in the European Union. The member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) highlighted the fact that for half the year or more the dairy herds in those European countries are housed indoors and are grain fed. Without the subsidies that they receive, they would not have a hope of competing against our products.

SPEECH.PARA: This is just another part of the artillery that the dairy industry is putting together. They are prepared to contribute more, as a result of this bill, to research and development through the AAHC. They recognise that it is incredibly important that we maintain a healthy herd in Australia. We have to be continually on the lookout for the new diseases that are developing. We have seen what happened with world beef consumption as a result of mad cow disease in Britain. It was not anywhere near Australia but it had a detrimental effect on the consumption, world wide, of beef. That is just part of the problem that our beef industry faces.

But the dairy industry continues to improve. In those early days there was a great rationalisation in the numbers of dairy farms. Those farms have got bigger and more efficient. We are going to go in 1996 from producing 9.055 million litres to 9.411 million litres. The value of exports is going to go from $1.905 billion to $2.122 billion. A lot of people lose sight of the fact that Australia is a major exporter of primary products and, of course, the dairy industry is very important at the centre of that.

I want to make a comment on the importance of undertaking initiatives as the industry and the government are with the introduction of this bill where that levy is going to be increased. I think the member for Corangamite alluded to the amount of money that producers would be paying in this levy. But the more important point is the principle of having the levy paid directly from the producer into that fund, which all goes to research and development, so that it is completely transparent. It is not going through their industry organisations. As is pointed out in the explanatory memorandum and in the Bills Digest, this has been supported by industry.

The Bills Digest states that the doubling of the levy rate has the support of the Australian Dairy Industry Council, so they understand that they have to continually protect the product that we have and the reputation that we have. Australia has a fantastic reputation as far as primary products are concerned. We have to continue to protect that. The government recognises that. We recognise that we have to protect that reputation through the funding that we provide to AQIS and in continually improving the processes that AQIS undertakes.

I was interested in some comments in a publication called Australian Commodities, which listed the figures I quoted earlier in relation to the capacity of milk production in Australia and the value of those exports to our economy. But the article also had some comments about world price forecasts. World prices for manufactured dairy products are forecast to rise. The article says:

World cheese prices are forecast to increase by around five per cent to average $US2,390 a tonne in 1997‐98. The expected stronger growth in prices for cheese products compared with other dairy products reflects continuing strong demand growth and reduced volumes of subsidised European Union cheese exports as part of WTO commitments.

The European Union is expected to be able to meet WTO commitments because strong internal demand for cheese, particularly in Germany, and a slower growth in EU cheese production is likely to reduce internal pressures for increasing export subsidies.

Something that I continually raise in this place is my concern and my healthy scepticism about trade liberalisation. Australia has gone well down that path by comparison to other nations around the world, particularly in the dairy industry.

We had a very successful structure established within the dairy industry. It was not being subsidised by taxpayers; it was within the industry, supporting the development of export markets. I am referring to what originally started as the Kerin plan. Everybody in the industry contributed to that because everybody benefited; whether they were providing manufacturing milk or market milk, everybody benefited. That has been acceptable. But with the finalisation of the Uruguay Round and the establishment of the WTO, somebody, somewhere—whether it was in one of the European cities where these things are based, or in the WTO—decided that the mechanisms that had been established in the dairy industry were GATT illegal. So they had to be changed.

The industry, being as dynamic as it is, was able to deal with that quite expeditiously. They developed a mechanism whereby they could replace that original all‐milk levy with a contribution to develop export markets that was acceptable as far as the World Trade Organisation was concerned. We have done that and the industry has responded quite expeditiously, so they can continue in the positive manner that they have over many years. But we do not see that from the nations that we compete with for world export market share in this industry. Anybody who has travelled to Europe and raised the issue of the common agricultural policy with any of those European countries knows that you get met with a stony look and a blank wall with regard to any moves to address the inequities that that policy creates. Those are the sorts of mechanisms that we have to compete against.

I still question the pace of change. We are being asked in Australia, in my view, to lead the way with regard to trade liberalisation, tariff reductions, getting rid of subsidies and the impediments to the clear transparent forms of trade. But my view is that we are not following the rest of the world; we are leading the rest of the world. We are trying to lead by example in Australia. And let us not be deceived in this, that Australia has a small population, a small economy by world standards and we are not leading anybody. We have not got the muscle to push other nations around, and I believe that we should be a little more diligent with regard to our industries in Australia, monitor how it is travelling overseas and do what we have got to do to keep pace. We all support trade liberalisation, but not at the expense of Australian industry and certainly not at the expense of the Australian dairy industry.

There is an expected continuing growth in Australian milk production, and the expansion in Australian milk supply is expected to continue in 1997‐98 with production forecast to increase by 3.9 per cent. This growth is based on a forecast increase in cow numbers and on milk yields returning to their longer‐term trend following the dry conditions in 1995‐96—that came out of that journal again.

I think that the member for Corio—and I did not hear the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) before him—was criticising again government members' contributions to debate on legislation that is relative to the dairy industry on the basis that we are continually crowing about what a good industry it is and how well it is going. It is going well. Those figures substantiate it. We understand that there are very dry conditions in Victoria, but in times past there have been very dry conditions in New South Wales and in other dairy production areas. That is not the fault of the industry. The industry as a whole is progressing well and is performing extremely well.

And as an individual that represents an electorate that has a predominant primary industry, the dairy industry, I will continue to get up in this place and represent the views of the dairy farmers in my electorate. They have progressed and gone with the times and, in my view, the dairy industry leads our other agricultural production industries in Australia, in terms of what its farmers have done in developing their industries through self‐help. They do not come around with their hands out to government and say, `You prop us up. You do this. You do that.' They are proactive.

The measure that we are debating today in this dairy produce levy bill is a proactive move, supported by the industry. They are going to increase the levies payable so that they can ensure the protection of the health of the herd in Australia and they want to make those levies direct so that they are quite transparent. They do not want any organisations like the World Trade Organisation criticising Australian producers for being corrupt, or saying that it is another hazy sort of subsidy. They want to make those levies direct.

So, it is important that we answer those criticisms that have been levelled at the government by the opposition members this morning in debating this bill. It is important that we recognise the job that has been done by the industry as a whole, and particularly the industry leaders over the last 10 or so years. We acknowledge that the initial development of the Kerin plan started this process, but it was not going to work without the absolute commitment of all the players in the industry: the producers, the processors and the exporters.

Against the odds and despite the corrupt practices of the European Union and, from time to time, the American dairy industry with their subsidies on milk powder into South‐East Asia, one of our major markets for milk powder, the industry has progressed.

And before I finish, I will make a comment on my views of how the dairy industry will deal with their situation as they face up to the reviews that are being implemented as a result of the implementation of the Hilmer national competition policy. As there is a requirement for a review of the activities of all the statutory marketing authorities across Australia, I believe that the dairy industry will come through that review process as having modernised itself, as being very competitive and as being able to maintain an argument that there is a provision of public benefit in the way the industry is structured now, without having to dismantle it for the sake of some ideological dogma.

I am pleased that the member for Corangamite is still here. I point out that this industry is unlike other primary industries in that it is genuine about the way it performs in the modern world as far as a liberalised market is concerned. I do not support change for change's sake. I do not support change just to ensure that something fits into an ideological model. I acknowledge that there are areas of our economy that need change, but I do not believe this is one of them.

This industry has made the hard yards over the years. It really is an example to other primary industries in this nation. They should get off their backsides and do something about their product, and not just produce a bit of excess and say, `We can't sell that in the cities so we will export it.' They should target their export markets and earn export dollars for the Australian economy. This industry is a perfect example of that.

Like the industry, I support what is proposed in this bill. I believe it will further encourage the development of an industry that is really going to be important to the Australian economy as we move towards the year 2000. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today in support of these important amendments contained in the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1997. The dairy industry is one of Australia's key export industries. Most of the Victorian part of that export industry is in the electorate of Murray.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill before the House today does a number of things. It imposes a levy on milk producers to fund the contribution of the dairy industry to the Australian Animal Health Council. It also doubles the maximum research levy rate which may be prescribed.
The Australian Animal Health Council is Australia's peak animal health body. Its main function is to ensure that our animal health standards are world best.

As the previous speaker—the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile)—said, there is no room today in our highly competitive markets for food and fibre for any industry that is less than world best. All industry has to be competitive in terms of its costs. Those costs include the amount of dollars that have to be spent on animal medication, in making sure that animal health is always at a peak. Our reputation in Australia for the export of animals and dairy product is beyond reproach in terms of its safety for human consumption.

The Australian Animal Health Council is funded by Commonwealth, state, territory and industry contributions. Until now, the dairy industry has contributed to this organisation through the surplus moneys paid to the Dairy Research and Development Corporation—these were left over when the exotic animal diseases program ended—and also through grants from the Australian Dairy Corporation.

Other industries like beef, wool, sheep production and so on agreed last year to a package which introduced a similar system to the one that is now before the House. That package received bipartisan support in both chambers, and the support of the minor parties and independents in the Senate. These amendments have wholehearted support throughout Australia, given that they seek to give an industry more self‐sufficiency and more dollars to make sure that we have disease free status for our dairy production.

The activities of the Australian Animal Health Council are crucial to Australia as we seek not only to reach world best—I suggest we are just about there at the moment with our dairy production—but to maintain that footing in our highly competitive markets. Therefore, the importance of world‐best research and development in the areas of animal health cannot be underestimated.

The Australian Animal Health Council, when it was established in 1995, was in many respects ahead of its time. It recognised the significance of partnerships for growth between industry and government. It was a model advocated by the Nairn report for adoption in relation to plants. This council recognises that there are important animal health issues which cross industry boundaries. They must be responded to nationally in a coordinated manner. All of the Australian industry needs to be involved.

BREAK.PARA: Our continued growth in export development across all of our agricultural industries is dependent on our being able to demonstrate the highest possible standards of animal health and quarantine services in Australia, particularly in relation to border checks and risk analysis assessment. Our budget, just announced last night, adds substantially to this country's ability to put in place world best quarantine services. More than $70 million are now going to be dedicated to ensuring—as we have ever more visitors to Australia—that we can stand up and do the best possible to stop diseased animals or plants from coming into this country.

We have the good news that the Olympic Games will be here shortly. Of course, that exposes us to many more pressures at the borders. We expect a great number of visitors. We will have to make sure that our quarantine services are up to speed and that the people coming to our Olympic Games are not hampered or held up at our airports but, at the same time, are exposed to the most rigorous testing of any product that they might bring in inadvertently—or perhaps deliberately—that could put our animal or plant industries at risk.

It was a very important initiative in our budget last night, and it shows that our government understands the significance of agribusiness in Australia. It not only gives lip‐service to the importance of the agribusiness industries but it also puts the dollars there to make sure that we can sustain our world best practices. Where we are still a little short and need more research—perhaps in introducing more feedlot technology for some of our animals, for example, our poultry or our piggery industries; or introducing new forms of agriculture—we will take on board world best practice. We will test that world best practice in Australia and make sure that none of our changes in animal husbandry are ever compromised in terms of the disease factors that could be introduced with new systems.

The advantage of this amendment is that the levy allows the Australian Animal Health Council to plan, coordinate and have total industry involvement and cooperation across the nation. It is exactly what we need and it is what this bill promises to deliver.

I hardly need to say that the dairy industry is one of our most successful agribusiness stories in Australia, and the previous speaker acknowledged that. The dairy industry in Australia has a long history. It began as the milk cow of the early settlers; a few more cows were milked; the billy was taken around; and the milk was sold in an unpasteurised form. We used our dairy industry as a means of settling a lot of our returned servicemen after World War I and World War II. The industry has played a great role in our social engineering in Australia.

Today, the management of our dairy industry has nothing to do with social engineering. It is businesslike in every way and shape. In fact, in the electorate of Murray, it is world best in terms of its current technology. Its cost competitiveness has been recognised by joint ventures with Snow Brand, one of Japan's leading dairy manufacturers, which has come and joined forces with our Tatura Milk Products factory in Tatura. Together, they manufacture infant formula to the highest standards of hygiene. That infant formula is re‐exported throughout South‐East Asia.

Very recently, we had another greenfield development when Mitsubishi and Meiji joined Murray Goulburn at Cobram. In recognition of the long‐term sustainability of our dairy industry, they entered into an agreement. They now manufacture infant formula in conjunction with one of our dairy icons, Murray Goulburn, and they, too, export that infant formula into South‐East Asia.

Quite clearly, if there was ever a major disease threat in Australia, those exports would be compromised—infant formula or any form of food—as they are highly susceptible to consumer lack of confidence. In Australia, we are preparing our industry with this funding levy to ensure that we are always on the front foot when it comes to doing the research and development, to ensure that we have the best information, the best advice and the best management practices on our dairy farms.

The electorate of Murray is one of Australia's largest producers of dairy product, in our Goulburn, Loddon and Murray valleys and it is the home of Australia's dairy export industry. In particular, besides the infant formula that goes straight out into South‐East Asia, we are also targeting the high value added ends of the markets in Japan, Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore. We are already experiencing some of the biggest market growth in Japan, where we are neck and neck with New Zealand in claiming about one‐third of that export market for our dairy product. As well, within our own domestic market for dairy products, we have some of the highest dairy product consumption in the world, and so it is equally important to make sure that our domestic consumers are protected from any disease that could enter the food chain and jeopardise both the consumption of products and human health in Australia.

We have already, in the dairy industry, a number of support programs. They have, over the years, helped our industry to grow from its infancy and to establish a form of dairy production which does not depend on artificial feeding of animals all through winter. We still have range reared animals to a very large extent in Australia, and many would argue that this is the healthiest way to produce dairy product: beta carotene from the sun is still to be found in our dairy products. The previous government support programs have been always of enormous support to the Australian industry. Now, of course, that dairy industry has come of age. It does not need, and has not asked, in recent times, for handouts. The levy system, which involves our dairy producers contributing towards their R&D costs, is the sign of a mature industry with mature members who understand that the industry needs to stand on its own feet.

The industry does look to government to maintain a fair and equitable trading regime in our region and to make sure that our quarantine services are as good as they can possibly be. It looks to our government to insist that the tariff regimes that we face in other nations should be brought down, in line with WTO obligations and commitments. But, in this bill, we are certainly not asking for any form of subsidy, handout or support. As I say, this bill is evidence of a mature industry that can stand on its own two feet and that understands that it needs to make a contribution so that it can be in control of its future. The Australian Animal Health Council levy will ensure that we can be world's best, cost competitive, and that both Australia and overseas countries continue to benefit from some of the world's best and safest dairy product.

I am very pleased to be able to support this amendment bill today. I believe, as I said before, that it is a mark of a mature industry, an industry that understands what it has to do to stay world's best.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks to the Labor Party!
—I do not really think so. I commend the bill to the House.

—I understand that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is unable to be present but will be represented by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), whom I invite to come to the front bench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As Mr Deputy Speaker said, I am going to make some concluding remarks on the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill and cognate bill on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). Before I do that, I want to make some comments in relation to some of the criticisms that have been made from the other side of the House, and I will conclude with an outline of what the bills seek to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, let me say that the shadow minister's performance here clearly underlines his position as remaining very much in the shadows for an awfully long time. He really was not quite across the issue at all. The comments made from the other side of the House were in relation to the government's support for, and commitment to, research and development. Let me make it quite clear that we do fund research and development on a dollar for dollar basis: a dollar from the government for every dollar contributed by the industry, up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. Last night, that commitment was locked up in the federal budget; so any suggestion coming from the other side of the House that we are not committed to delivering on research and development is a fallacy.

Another benefit of the coalition in government has been our responsible approach to the management of the economy of our nation. This has had a dramatic effect on the small businesses of Australia, the primary producers of Australia and, in reference to this bill, the dairy industry in this nation.

Since coming to government 14 months ago, official interest rates have fallen by 1.5 per cent. Every 0.5 per cent reduction in official interest rates delivers a saving of $90 million to the farm sector alone. It benefits all farmers, because everyone can participate in those lower interest rates. It also helps the processing and manufacturing sector of the dairy industry, to which this bill refers.

Our financial management has seen official interest rates at their lowest point for 30 years—unlike Labor's disaster, where they took interest rates to the highest we have ever seen in this nation. So Labor members should not come into the Main Committee and lecture us about the budget last night. They should get their facts straight.

It is acknowledged that drought is starting to return to some parts of Australia, and we acknowledge that there are some dairy farmers in those areas who will have their capacity to maintain production affected. We are concerned that drought is once again creeping into many parts of Australia, but let me remind the other side of the House that it was this government that extended by six months the exceptional circumstance provision for that recovery phase for those producers who had come out of drought.

I might remind the other side of the House that they had a recovery phase of six months post the revocation of drought status from an individual or a region. We extended that at the end of last year by a further six months, effectively doubling the recovery phase. The shadow minister is not in the House, and he is obviously going to remain very much in the shadows whilst ever he comes in peddling this misinformation.

We do understand the plight of rural Australia. We understand also the importance of the dairy industry to regional Australia. Many members on our side of parliament have indicated the importance of the dairy industry and the importance of this bill to the dairy industry, because the dairy industry is one of our great success stories in agriculture in Australia.

Not only have we seen the dairy industry modernise itself, we have also seen it become more and more world competitive. It is important we continue to support them in their efforts to make sure they remain cost competitive. The latest commodity bulletin, Australian Commodities, Vol. 4, No. 1, March 1997, shows that the prices received from processed commodities and dairy products will increase over 1997‐98 from an average of $US1,530 a tonne to $US1,970. That is an increase in world prices for butter and skim milk powder.

If we are to make the most of those forecast price increases and let the dairy farmers capture their share of that market, we have got to make sure we provide them with the best possible economic climate in this country, we support them with research and development and we make sure the changes to the industrial relations legislation allow for the processing plants and the farm labour side of things to be world competitive. Otherwise, they will not make the most of this opportunity and avail themselves of the increased prices and demand that are forecast to flow into the world dairy market.

The amendments contained in these bills will assist the industry enhance its capacity to undertake animal health and research and development activities in the future. This will safeguard the industry and lead to further improvements in our competitiveness in both domestic and international markets and increased profitability for all sectors of the industry.

The other important point is that the Australian dairy industry has given its full support to these legislative amendments contained in these bills. So we not only have the support of the dairy industry, but the government understands the need for these bills. We have supported it and we are not doing anything that is in conflict with the dairy industry.

In conclusion, I want to say that we will deliver on R&D. It is the base for building a more productive agricultural sector in Australia. We will deliver in terms of our Natural Heritage Trust Fund which will flow into many regional areas of Australia and benefit the agricultural sector and, at the same time, create jobs in regional Australia. We are also committed, as per the budget last night, to making sure that our quarantine service is not underfunded, that it has the funds it requires to make sure that we remain free of diseases which could accidentally arrive on our shores. I thank all those members from both sides who have made a contribution and I commend the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

TITLE.XREF: AUSTRALIAN ANIMAL HEALTH COUNCIL (LIVE‐STOCK INDUSTRIES) FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.

BREAK.PARA: Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP
